results.content: Because it's making something I've been struggling with for a week, going-in in the deep end made murky with lots of other, rendered co-morbid, considerations, ... already, in just one day, almost "easy" to understand.  The exercise so far, in section 2, presents something of a jump in skill requirement contrasting from the gentle course delivery - it does require knowledge & understanding, and insight into how to apply, advanced C# topics as covered in Mosh's C# Advanced course - but as a reward ramps up confidence in using MVC very quickly.    So far I'm very happy - money well spent.  It does what it says on the tin ... lead you by the hand from A to B in a nice way.  Maybe it leaves out some detail here or there, sidesteps a few things for all I know, but anything left-out will be much more manageable once I'm armed with the skills clearly taught in this course (based on how its gone so far).
results.content_html: Because it's making something I've been struggling with for a week, going-in in the deep end made murky with lots of other, rendered co-morbid, considerations, ... already, in just one day, almost "easy" to understand. The exercise so far, in section 2, presents something of a jump in skill requirement contrasting from the gentle course delivery - it does require knowledge & understanding, and insight into how to apply, advanced C# topics as covered in Mosh's C# Advanced course - but as a reward ramps up confidence in using MVC very quickly. So far I'm very happy - money well spent. It does what it says on the tin ... lead you by the hand from A to B in a nice way. Maybe it leaves out some detail here or there, sidesteps a few things for all I know, but anything left-out will be much more manageable once I'm armed with the skills clearly taught in this course (based on how its gone so far).

I needed an MVC refresher and this course provides an excellent grounding in MVC using real-world examples. The pace is perfect, however, Mosh assumes you have a reasonable grasp of C#. The exercises help cement the techniques learned.
There's a lot of material in this course and I can't recommend it highly enough. Thank you Mosh!

results.content:
I am an experienced Web Developer with over 8 years of experience developing web application in other MVC frameworks. Due to a recent job switch I had to take ASP.net course and based on my experience with other courses on Udemy I decided to take this course here.  I typically avoid giving bad reviews even if I am highly disappointed with the service but this course is far more disappointing than anything I have ever came across when it comes to online courses. From the beginning of the course there was a huge gap between instructions given by Mosh and code on my local machine ( I am using Visual Studio 2017) . As an experienced developer in other MVC frameworks I somehow managed to navigate around the problems myself and learn along the way but 3 hours into the course when he starts to deal with Entity Framework and Migrations I realized that the time I spent has been a complete waste.   He does not give any instructions on what database to use and how to set up the entity framework with any database. He directly starts enabling the migrations which yields all sort of problems which are not resolved even after spending 2 hours on getting that up and running. I am extremely disappointed with the instructor and the quality of this course. I am not concerned about the money here but the time spent on this crap course is what bothers me the most. I could have spent this time in doing something more productive. 

Thank you for nothing Mosh. Your course is going to archives now !

results.content: This course is excellent! It covers a lot of ground. I was already familiar with ASP.NET and Entity Framework, so I was pleasantly surprised by how much I learned. Mosh is an outstanding teacher -- one of the best on Udemy. I only wish he had released the advanced pattern/architecture follow-up course that he mentioned at the end of this one. That said, this course is wonderful and most of the material is still quite relevant with ASP.NET Core. Today you would probably want to use React, Angular or Vue instead of jQuery, but otherwise the techniques shown here are great. I highly recommend this course to anyone interested in learning MVC, even Core.

Today you would probably want to use React, Angular or Vue instead of jQuery, but otherwise the techniques shown here are great. I highly recommend this course to anyone interested in learning MVC, even Core.

results.content:
Yes, you see that Mosh has experience with ASP .NET MVC and you profit from that.

Unfortunately, the course is broken and really needs an update.

After starting explicitly with a project without ASP .NET Identity, he suddenly has it in his project. As a student it's really hard to get everything working, you have to start from 0 again and feel left alone.

That was not the only time this happens, if you watch his Github history, some changes suddenly appear, without being mentioned anywhere and you have to find you way into this the hard way.

You feel very frustrated after these videos.

On the other hand, Mosh also tries sell his other courses all the time... after selling you a COMPLETE course.

Dude I have just payed money for two of your courses. I don't want to buy 3 of your other courses just to "fully" understand this one. Just tell me what I need to know in a short way.

Anyway there are lot's of other bad points too... Mosh builds denormalized tables in this course and calls it necessary optimization. Exactly AFTER talking about premature optimization ... DUDE just wtf? Denormalization brings a whole class of possible errors into your application ... especially regarding miscalculations e.g. in updates. 
EDIT: really funny, he makes the mistake i warned about above... he calculates some row values in a non thread-safe way. This can result in data inconsistency in production systems!

This course still has value, but not as much as I thought it had, and it also teaches some bad practices, that can't be argued about!

results.content:
Mosh's style of teaching is simply superb! I love the fact that he has a strong opinion and that he has a reason for doing everything he does. 

Throughout the course, you'll often hear him say things such as "I find Microsoft's approach a bit poor because [...]". I believe this is the way every course should be taught - always explaining the reason for choosing a certain approach or style.

At times, when Mosh doesn't have a strong preference for a coding style or pattern, he will explain the pros and cons of both, and he'll say something like "I'll leave it up to you to choose the solution that you think works best ." This is simply brilliant.

The only downside to this course is that it's about the last generation of ASP.NET. Mosh does point out throughout the course where ASP.NET has changed, but I would have preferred if were about ASP.NET Core.

results.content:
So... I haven't watched everything, but being a curious guy I wanted to know about a bit more regarding the different components of the project. The thing is the instructor was doing a great job teaching what the course was offering but not to its full intent. What I mean by saying that is right from the beginning after the first section I felt if the Instructor explained everything from the perspective of an empty project, I would have understood more about the different parts. Instead it felt like I was left hanging with more questions about how a simple thing as a _layout.html page is supposed to be created.

When buying a course that says "the complete MVC 5 course", I don't expect jumping into an already functional project an adding to whats already there. I expect to learn to add all the different components by myself. 

That is why i give this course a 3 out of 5.

results.content:
Mosh does not ever explain the solutions, but forces you to look for others to explain. The solutions are not always completed in github where he expects you to find it. 

He never explains API validation and security setup, but expects you to figure it out on your own.  

Is it so hard for Mosh to make videos going over the solutions to the exercises to help ensure the students learned and executed it correctly. If this were a face-to-face school environment, the students with trouble to go to the teacher or ask during class. Without contact to Mosh (h does not answer all the questions), we are left to help from others (who are not paid for the course.) 

I would be interested in other videos, but the lack of solutions and explanations has me hesitant to spend any additional money on this site.

results.content:
OK, you think you know the basics? Well, maybe you do or do you…? That's what I thought before I took this course. I watched couple of videos on Pluralsight and thought I am ready for something bigger. But don’t let it bother you that this is a 'beginner' course. There is certainly some of that here as well. What you’ll find here is a good and solid knowledge that every person, who took a first step into the MVC world, needs to know. The course has lots of good examples that could be used in the real world application. Exercise tasks could be quite challenging at times. And that’s OK, that’s why we here – to learn. Plus Mosh comes up with solutions that quite simple and you’d think “Wow, now why didn’t I think of that?” So prepare your brain to be stretched in all directions and DO THE EXCERSISES if you want to take full advantage of the course.
One thing I’d prefer Mosh would do is to provide a full working code at the end of each section. I really needed one because I messed up somewhere in my code and it took me a while to find a bug. This could be challenging if you are completely new to MVC. 
Overall: fantastic course, great pace and very nicely composed. I give it 5 Stars. So great job, Mosh and keep up a good work.

results.content:
Great tutorial with relevant content. Very well explained and at a reasonable pace. I love the additional cheat sheets which will serve as  a great reference in the future. I would love to see code downloadable throughout  the stages like you see with branches in git. The code is available for download as a completed project with comparable merge changes accessible in git however a downloadable version at each stage would serve as a great addition.
A great Tutorial overall and I have and will be purchasing other courses  in his series. 
As an addition after watching the complete course I would definitely recommend this tutor as he has a very high quality product and covers all aspects of development from planning to deployment as well as optimisation techniques.

results.content: I really think this course is great. Of course one can talk about this topic in more depth and detail, but I think that would be confusing on this level. This course has its strength in its selection of topics and details which should be covered and which should be skipped for the first time. It has a really smooth path from the beginning to a reliable knowledge of building an MVC web app. The border areas are mentioned and basically explained, but not in a too detailed way. They are mentioned just to know the basics about them, but the focus always stays on the more important parts. So in a nutshell, this course covers this complex topic with a good selection of subjects, with a nice order of them and with a well structured buildup. The presentor has a good and plain english and uses it with a good style. Clear, straightforward and funny sometimes. I can suggest to anybody who would like to start with MVC or who has a basic knowledge, but would like to structure it.

I can suggest to anybody who would like to start with MVC or who has a basic knowledge, but would like to structure it.

results.content:
The instructor knows his stuff, and presents all the information clearly and in perfect pace.
EDIT: I really enjoyed the course...until the API was introduced. It was confusing to implement that along side the standard Controllers, and required a lot of back-and-forth and deleting previously written code, especially once the jQuery was used to render the Views. 
I wish the instructor stayed on the topic of MVC and pure back end, and didn't mix API, or even jQuery into it - that could be a separate course. The course fell into similar "trap" pretty much every MVC course falls into - it tries to pack too many different ways, frameworks, libraries, and technologies, that are out of the scope for the course to be effectively explained, and are simply used "as is" and turn the course into "monkey codes what monkey sees". I understand that in the real world, technologies are mixed together, however this is an MVC tutorial and I would prefer for it to concentrate on MVC without venturing too far out of the scope because without explanation, it only adds confusion while adding minimum (if any) real coding value.

results.content: Speaking as a professional educator for going on six years now, I know that this person may be knowledgeable about this content but is the poorest instructor I have encountered on Udemy in the past two years. His methods are in a way, lazy teaching. He instructs and briefly explains topics that take a moment to sink in. While his pace is commendable for the active learner, he leaves much to be desired for what exactly he is doing (ie, explain in lamen's terms). He leaves the learner scratching their head some and often doesn't explain any additional detail as to what should be done to pinpoint the issues. His solutions to exercises are simply "Go find it on my GitHub" which gets rather frustrating and difficult to navigate as this course isn't in sync with his files available on his GitHub account. Lastly, his expectations video is one of the most absurd, condescending messages I have ever heard from an instructor with the basic communication of "I'm good at what I do so if you have a problem with your code, it's your own fault and don't expect me to help fix it."

results.content:
This course is well presented and has a knowledgable tutor, but the details are rushed, I feel like i'm just being walked through putting together a simple app, but I'm not learning why I am doing these things, or what the context of making this application is. 

For example, the first exercise is a pretty standard "using what we've covered do X, Y & Z." but half of it has either not been covered at all (eg LINQ queries), or wasn't presented in context, so you don't really know where to start. The solution is simple pointing you to his Github so you end up just parroting the solution, again, not really learning anything.

I wouldn't mind so much if the steps for the exercise where broken down in more detail "Create new views for customers/movies etc" or pointed out there was new info to go look for "Google LINQ queries for completing X", I know troubleshooting and research is a key part of learning to Code (how I learnt others), but this just feels lazy.

I wouldn't recommend this course for beginners, people that have already started learning elsewhere and are comfortable, will probably find it fine. The exercise and "solution" just feels like he had enough recording for the day and wanted to wrap it up quickly. 

I'll complete the course regardless, but i'm a lot less enthusiastic than when I started.

results.content: I had high hopes early on as Mosh seems to have a friendly and knowledgeable presentation style. But then in Section 3 things really start accelerating. Code that we never create in class suddenly appears in Mosh's version with no explanation. It took me 4 hours to get Migrations running because every solution provided didn't work. He just rushes through everything, never taking the time to explain anything or remember that WE ARE BEGINNERS at this, you can't just shove a bunch of code down our throats and just automatically assume that we get it. Plus his dogmatic insistence on EF code-first (do it my way or you're a bad programmer) goes totally against my experience and intuition and yet he barely ever explains what he's doing.  It's nice having the code in GitHub, but even there the code is poorly organized, we work on a file in the course but then it's not in the solution! It's completely disorganized and disconnected. And the solutions to exercises are never presented in a video format so we can see what he's doing and why he's doing it. Just a major disappointment. I had high hopes early on but just another out-of-touch instructor who can't seem to grasp the concept that his students are beginners, and then worst of all, ignores questions and abandons his students after taking their money. I will be getting a refund!

results.content: Very good beginner course to MVC. The only reason for 4 stars is due to it being outdated. You can still learn the basics and how to do things with MVC, but the database part is completely different. So I would recommend using VS 2013 if you are going to take this course. I was able to follow along with VS 2019 except for the database migrations. You can get around this, but it takes some know how. Mosh does a great job explaining things.

results.content: Very impressed with the course content. It did a great job at walking me through each of the MVC components, then giving exercises which allowed me to try it on my own. You end up building a working app, which is great! You will also learn some best practices and modern development methodologies. Code first is the exact opposite of what I've been learning in college, but it seems to be a much more productive approach. It is a very faced paced course, and I had to pause the videos a lot to catch up.

results.content:
After completing the entire course and all exercises I can say that Mosh gives you a pretty nice fundamental knowledge and best practices of ASP.NET, Entity Framework and MVC 5. 

BUT...!

If you have no previous programming experience this course seems to be undoable. Some stuff is outdated and you need to find some solutions on your own. If you don't know C#, OOP or SQL this course is not the best place to be for you.
This one is definately a course for advanced programmers that want to learn new skills. Take a look at Moshs C# beginners courses first if you don't have any previous experience.

Keep it up!

results.content: The best course to learn ASP.NET MVC - from the great trainer, Mosh. He's very experienced and this course is structured in such a way that it covers both frond-end and back-end extensively. The reason I emphasize on this is - I've gone through other courses from different authors years back, but none had covered with such content. I highly recommend this course and importantly, practice every exercise in all the section to enjoy hands-on. Thanks very much on such a quality content, Mosh.

results.content:
This is more of an advertisement for his other courses than a complete C# ASP.NET MVC 5 Course. 

He does do a good job of quickly going though the concepts without glossing over things or having sloppy presentation. 

However, even in what he does cover, the practices taught here are pretty horrible. In the name of his "code first" mantra, he is literally hard coding database values into empty database migration files in raw SQL. 

This is not code first, this is "some code, some data, all mixed in". Just a quick Google searched returned that you should be putting seed data into Migrations > Configuration.cs > Seed. Not some random migration file in raw SQL. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/web-api/overview/data/using-web-api-with-entity-framework/part-3.
results.content_html:

results.content:
I like the mix of very careful step by step explanations followed by "throw you in the deep end" exercises. Ive seen some comments complaining about how the exercises dont have enough guidance but honestly thats the best way to do it. If someone cant figure that stuff out by searching, experimenting and asking around on forums then they really arnt cut out to be a dev. 

Those moments, where you feel profoundly lost, followed by making progress one step at a time until you solve the problem is where the real learning happens, and this course balances out well. The explanations are clear and concise when needed, and just open ended enough to model real world problem solving the rest of the time.

 Keep up the good work dude ill probably buy some of your other courses.

results.content:
The author has promised a comprehensive view of the ASP.NET MVC 5 framework. In reality, I got that and way more.


Some of the best points of this course:
- clear (audio and video presentation);
- logically structured with sections that derive from one another;
- really clear examples (e.g. it feels like the author has a good intuition of what I am about to ask and right away he's already answering it);
- (!) one fat start goes simply to the fact that the author briefly introduces new modern web technologies and useful developmental tools.  Glipmse, Angular2, ReSharper etc. -- It's definitely worth at least knowing about them.


Few things I found difficult: lambda expressions, linq queries and asynchronous method execution. It's fair to mention that I come from PHP and my C# background is fairly limited. However, the author warns you about these advanced concepts and also offers you a course on them. 


Probably the most difficult part for me was coding without really knowing what Entity Framework 6 (EF6) is doing behind the scenes. Again, the author warns you that he will not go into details and offers you additional resources. At first I wondered why Mosh is taking this complicated approach and not simply stick to ADO.NET. By the end of the course I was actually grateful he did introduce EF6. This is my argument:
- ASP.NET MVC 5 is an extremely powerful framework that easily couples with other modern technologies. Using it with outdated practices would mean wasting its potential.
- ASP.NET MVC 5 is really suitable for large projects where scalability is an important concern.


All these ideas, along with the skills to tackle them, are offered in this course in an easy to grasp manner. Five stars for discussing not only basic principles, but proving a comprehensive view on how I can use this in the real world. 
Thanks for this course!

results.content:
The course is not for beginners. As newbie to Asp.mvc the instructor at times feels the need to  short-cut a section.  One Ex is the solution in section 1. When the instructor deciedes to skip to github link instead of giving us hands-on solution. the other is the "Entity framework section" which  i found no use for.., because Mosh decidede to skip most of how to setup a database,.not to mention:  the basic of downloading the various package that needs to be pre-installed before begin with imgration-part. This course should have an instruction-book spend to much time browsing the web before figuring out something so simple  was missing in the application,  due to the Mosh either skipping that part or cuttinging it out of the video... I honest cant say which is worse. I may reviste this course in the future when have more understanding of Asp, but currently,  iam sure mosh-course is not the place i would begin my journey into ASP.MVC...

UPDATE: Back after a crash course in asp, and still stand by the previous outburts of the short-coming of this course...but decides to update  the review due harsh-bias and Mosh course does bring some goods and ides to table. But still holding back the next golden  star....until Mosh decides to stepup and UPDATE this course

results.content:
I must say that THIS is the way to learn.
Mosh does go in detail about the important things you need to know while providing you with extra resources, and there are no lines of code which are not explained.
The best part of this are the exercises, the sections might be 30-60 minutes long, but the exercises, if really followed through, can take another hour or two to figure out and really dive deep into how to make it work. 
At the end, while Mosh does not go over the solution, he points you to his Github repository where you can find the solutions with comments and discussions over why he did what he did, this allowing the student to get a bit more familiar with using Github.
I wish there were more courses with exercises like these!
Great job Mosh!

results.content:
Great course so far (completed 28%). The only downsides are Mosh talking pretty fast and throwing you in the deep when it comes to the exercices. I already have some .NET knowledge, but the exercices will be pretty hard for beginners and we don't get any explanation afterwards - only some commits on GitHub.

But don't let these things scare you, the course is great and will get you going in .NET MVC 5

results.content:
So far the instructor has been covering the basics in a way that is easy to understand. He eschews advanced topics in favor of getting working examples. I like the way he presents the material; in a clear, yet friendly and informal, style. 
When I first learned MVC (many, many moons ago), the level of exposure to concepts like Routes, Controllers, Actions, Models, and Views required reading dozens of pages in books full of typos. 
The instructor’s methods already feel superior, and we’ve only just begun.

results.content:
Great content so far, but I've taken two stars away for the following reasons:

1) Course is a bit outdated (4 years old now) and requires some areas to be updated.
2) The solutions are extremely lazy. He just links to his github and pretty much says "Figure it out" and suggesting you look at it in split view rather than walking you through. He claims they are well documented/commented but they are not. There's one comment in the entire solution that I'm looking at.

Third edit: Okay, this is just unbearable at this point. There are SO many things that Mosh does not mention that he just expects you to have in your project, things that if you don't do them in the beginning will break your project later (like user authentication). I am spending WAY WAY more time trying to fill the gaps of this course than on the course itself and at this point I'm just going to write it off and go with a free option.

The ONLY reason I'm not giving this a 1 star is because I know that this content was at one point relevant and Harlan the teaching assistant is actually useful and responsive (Mosh, though knowledgable, does not respond in this course)

results.content: My problem with most courses when they cover a large subject matter is that they always gloss over relevant details. This one is no different. I just watched a video on migrations. There was not enough detail about migrations, what they are and why they are necessary, what are the migration options or the package manager console. It's pretty much "type this and this will happen". If there is ever a problem while performing this process in the real world I feel I will be screwed. Fortunately, I am used to this level of instruction and I have a library of resources to help me through my development problems.

results.content: Mosh's work has been solid for the 3 courses I've taken so far but this one felt slightly off. First, parts definitely seem dated. That comes with the territory I suppose so I don't want to harp on that. My biggest grief was getting to Section 6. Everything up to that point went well and, for the most part, all built on each other. Then, we scrap what feels like everything just to learn APIs which were confusing and the pacing felt too fast. Then we get to JQuery and it was like reading hieroglyphics. I felt extremely confused after this and basically gave up. I gave you four stars for this work because I really enjoyed everything through section 5 and I learned a lot. I think if you had a course on just JQuery or a suitable replacement it would be appropriate and I'd probably buy it but to include it here just added a lot of confusion and frustration. Overall, a great course.

results.content:
Great course!   I really enjoyed the design and flow of the instruction.   The lessons were clear and easy to understand.  The exercises were challenging but reasonable.    

I felt pretty confident in my skills until I went to apply them to a ASP.NET Core project.  There are many differences, but I was able to use the course concepts to stay on track.   However, it is probably worth updating this course to reflect these framework changes.
results.content_html:

results.content:
Mosh is an excellent instructor, who can teach more topics in very less amount of time.  I am a bit disappointed with this course as there are many important topics untouched.  Below are my few cents,

1. Handling exceptions would have better explained instead of simply using the ELMAH library.
2. No coverage for the topics like custom action filters, exception filters etc.
3. Would be better if explained about custom model binding and other internals instead of going deeper on Entity Framework (Since Mosh provided a separate course on EF alone).
4. Explained Repository pattern in an excellent manner, but didn't said anything on dependency injection which was used in the source code provided.

Apart from the above it's an excellent course if we want to quickly get into this.
results.content_html:

results.content:
A lot of students seem angry at this course at the moment. I recently read one comment by a very angry student from all reasons I give below.

Most questions in the Q/A go unanswered. It seems most students don't get the support they need. Most questions aren't about misunderstanding concepts, they are technical questions as to why their programs aren't working having followed the instructions.

The course feels rushed. It seems easy to miss an important setup step leading to missing dependencies, such as installing entityframework etc as they are rushed through.

Code examples are on a master branch on github. It would be easier if there was a download for each section.

I tried to follow the lectures by adding code with the videos. This led to a broken program. I don't know why, but statistically I suspect I won't get a response.

The code examples are broken. I ran a checkout for the section I was on. The code silently crashed. I also downloaded the head commit of the finished program. That also crashed.

This course feels like it has been abandoned..

results.content:
This course is an excellent course for a number of reasons. The first is that Mosh will give little soundbites as to why something is there or the implications of a particular property or setting which of course couples the whole learning process together.
Secondly, it is an end to end course which I really liked coming from a beginner level on ASP.NET. 
Thirdly, technologies. How to approach a web site. Is it pure ASP.NET, WebAPI and client side with pros and cons. Finally, some fantastic little packages to install e.g. Glimpse, Toastr etc. which I was unfamiliar with. I have to admit by the end, the information was overwhelming but as you start to do your own projects I suspect this will become a handy reference tool also. You remember something you saw on the course, revisit it and implement. This course is excellent. There are so many take aways and you cannot help smiling when you see Mosh add in a package guide a few changes and your site looks so much nicer. Another great course from Mosh.

One suggestion for Mosh is that throughout the course we install many packages and I am sure there are others which are equally as powerful. It would be nice to have the package with a 1 line write up on what it does and where it is covered in the course. Then it becomes easy for us to use the course as a reference tool also.

results.content:
Overall a very good course about net mvc. Instructor uses detailed explanations that are easy to follow along with, code right along with him.  There are also well reasoned justifications for deviating from the standard .netmvc  ways of doing things when there is a better way.  MVC, REST, and Oauth are covered as well in the abstract which was above and beyond what I expected. You will also learn about EntitfyFramework, which is well done by the instructor.

This course would be perfect, except that it doesn't include anything about unit testing the web application you build. I think testing should start at the beginning, and in this context I think it should have begun in this introductory course.

Nonetheless I would recommend this course for anyone who want to learn net mvc, and have recommended it to my colleagues.

results.content:
This really is an excellent course - like the delivery of his other courses, Mosh remains on point, fast-paced and covers everything you need to know to get your first MVC 5 site up and running.

From simple model design through code-first database deployment, Razor syntax for dynamic page designs and form logic, and shipping your site, this course took me from C# hobbyist and occasional work-user to developing and deploying a data-driven website for a local charity.

Next up - taking the API design foundations from this course and combining them with the Angular client-side access materials from another of Mosh's courses and producing a full membership system with management interface.

If you're not sure whether to buy this course - take the plunge, it's worth it!

not all topics are covered in this course, the course is solely cover MVC, and not supporting topics like Entity Framework etc, so the instructor either refer to his other courses or self study.
Which is not what i hoped for comparing with other courses in udemy that covers end to end. 
However, i have to admit that i learned a lot from this course, but still not as much as i hoped for.
the course will only show you the steps of doing things with little explanation on why/how we do that. you will need to self study and spend a lot of time practicing the concepts to deeply understand.
many videos are outdated. the course is from 2016.
the exercises are great, but no videos on hand-on solution, just a github solution.
many questions are unanswered in Q&A

the course will only show you the steps of doing things with little explanation on why/how we do that. you will need to self study and spend a lot of time practicing the concepts to deeply understand.
many videos are outdated. the course is from 2016.
the exercises are great, but no videos on hand-on solution, just a github solution.
many questions are unanswered in Q&A

results.content: This course is a good overview and the exercises are real-world enough to be relevant.  However I have to deduct for the fact that this is now a 3 year old course with only minor updates, so that many of the 3rd party tools and packages used are not compatible with each other, and it requires a lot of hunting around to make adjustments.  Sure that's also a real world task, but it really slows your progress on exercises to a crawl sometimes and can be very discouraging when you can't find a solution to an outdated problem.

results.content:
Unfortunately, the course is broken and really needs an update.

You have to keep going to his github and copy code from there and learn from there, he teaches nothing.

After starting explicitly with a project without ASP .NET Identity, he suddenly has it in his project. As a student it's really hard to get everything working, you have to start from 0 again and feel left alone.

That was not the only time this happens, if you watch his Github history, some changes suddenly appear, without being mentioned anywhere and you have to find you way into this the hard way.

You feel very frustrated after these videos.

On the other hand, Mosh also tries sell his other courses all the time... after selling you a COMPLETE course.

Dude I have just payed money for two of your courses. I don't want to buy 3 of your other courses just to "fully" understand this one. Just tell me what I need to know in a short way.

Anyway there are lot's of other bad points too... Mosh builds denormalized tables in this course and calls it necessary optimization. Exactly AFTER talking about premature optimization ... DUDE just wtf? Denormalization brings a whole class of possible errors into your application ... especially regarding miscalculations e.g. in updates.

results.content: This is the worst course I've seen on Udemy. I like Mosh's other stuff well enough, but this one is extremely frustrating. I am using VS 2017 and everything fell apart at the unit on Migration. I tried several fixes. IN the end the answer seemed to be "start all over and make a few different selections at the initial set-up phase. Sorry, I'm not willing to do that. I put a lot of work into trying to understand the confusing instructions up to that point and getting the app running. The philosophy of making your students reach and push themselves is acceptable to a degree. But it can also be a facile way of excusing poor design and/or laziness on the part of the instructor. I would like my money back for this course.

results.content:
I am using Visual Studio 2019 (Community) and I've had to tweak a couple of things for the code shown in the videos to work. Also, the subtitles appear to be auto-generated and are not very accurate.

As I dig deeper into the course I bumped into two issues: First, in Visual studio 2019 the code to work with Identities is not included by default, so I had to create a new solution with the identity option selected and after that, I added the changes I had so far.

The second issue was related to the WebApiConfig.cs file which I had to download from the instructor Github, I must've missed the part where this file is added.

results.content: Before buying that course, I had some doubts. The course was published in April 2016 a lot of majority use ASP.NET Core 2.2, but I have liked other courses of Mosh Hamedani. So, I made the decision, but the expectations were not great. In reality, the course is awesome! Some things are changed nowadays, but ideas, best techniques, techniques are still useful. And I have to say that Moshfegh is a virtuoso teacher – he can highlight the most important thing. His explanation of the REST API concept is the clearest, as the other topics: Routing, Razer Syntax, Entities, Cross-site Request Forgery, DTOs, etc. I found a lot of new packages in the course: DataTables.net, Bootbox, Glimpse. The course is great! Thank you very much, Mosh!

results.content: The course itself is amazing. It has a perfect balance between usefulness, briefness and simplicity. Though some parts of the material are timed out already, so it would be really nice to renew it so that it would reflect the latest versions of everything. Not such a big deal for me personally, but might cause using some rather outdated practices by guys who are novices in programming. For instance, some choices could be really reconsidered now because of the possibility to use "nameof" construction introduced in C# 6 (I personally like using it in cshtml templates a lot; it allows to avoid silly mistakes when editing).
results.content_html: The course itself is amazing. It has a perfect balance between usefulness, briefness and simplicity. Though some parts of the material are timed out already, so it would be really nice to renew it so that it would reflect the latest versions of everything. Not such a big deal for me personally, but might cause using some rather outdated practices by guys who are novices in programming. For instance, some choices could be really reconsidered now because of the possibility to use "nameof" construction introduced in C# 6 (I personally like using it in cshtml templates a lot; it allows to avoid silly mistakes when editing).

results.content: I know PHP/MySQL but our tech stack at work is C#/ASP.NET. I was given a task at work to put together a simple webapp to improve a workflow, and needed a course to quickly learn ASP.NET MVC. I can say that this course is really exceeding my expectation. What you get with Mosh is real Software Development Craftsmanship. I'm really enjoying the course. You can tell he's very knowledgeable about the subject and passionate about sharing his knowledge. When I'm done with this course, I'll move on to his .Net Core and Angular course. 5 Stars!

Course was way too complicated for someone just starting out with ASP.NET and he started teaching how to create an application without knowing 99% percent of what was happening. I felt completely lost as when i tried to add something to the application there was almost always something wrong because of something we hadn't learned yet. I didn't complete this course but found another course on Pluralsight: Building a Web App with ASP.NET Core, MVC 6, EF Core, and Angular
by Shawn Wildermuth. He teaches from the ground up and I never felt like I was lost. If you are just starting out i would really recommend him.

results.content: Course is given on old IDE and recorded significant time ago. I've had lot of problems and spend lot of extra time due to different default options in VS2017 vs VS2013 as well as because some websites referred to by the course are now having different look and options. For instance, a difference in default Authentication option while creating a project forced me to re-create everything from the scratch and about a day of work additionally updating the code to recent state and re-creating the DB. Otherwise, the course was good enough. I would definitely recommend the instructor to update the course using most recent IDE (at least)

results.content: This was a great course and helped me build some web applications in work. What annoyed me though was the instructor goes really fast. I constantly had to rewind the video to see what he typed. Also since re-sharper is a paid tool, it shouldn't have been used for shortcuts throughout the course as it's unfair to those like me who can't afford it. I don't want to be too critical - I learned a great deal from the course and I had little to no prior experience with C#. If you're looking to learn the basics of MVC and learn how to think as a developer - i.e. researching documentation, using external libraries, etc with a view to putting it all together as an end product then this course will be very beneficial to you.

results.content:
I really enjoyed this course about MVC.

It was a first for me learning this pattern and it was made easy. This course offers insight into so many different techniques used by developers eg. Razor views, APIs, ajax etc. and really gives you a good introduction to each. I now know which areas I want to focus more on and will look into courses specifically focusing on those areas. The course was made a while ago with respect to dev terms and there are some changes which lead to issues in the lectures but all problems are solved in the Q/A section. 

And I guess now onto ASP.NET Core..

results.content:
Mosh does an excellent job of introducing the concepts of ASP.NET MVC 5. He gives good examples and explains the details of why it is good to do things one way over another. Mosh covers a little bit of the background and evolution of ASP.NET MVC so that students understand where it came from and how it got where it is. Moreover, he doesn't do this so much that the student gets bored.

The course offers excellent supplemental material that helps guide students, but doesn't handfeed them. Mosh uses a GitHub repository to store the example project so that students can see code changes and ask questions for clarification on specific lines of code. He also offers great exercises that challenge students to an acceptable degree and reinforce the knowledge being gained.

There are a few reasons why I don't give this course 5 stars. There are no disclaimers in the course description about the speed of the course, and the experience required is listed as "All levels". This is certainly not a course for pure beginners, and probably not even novices to programming. There are concepts and syntax that are used, but not explained in depth. I would caution anyone wanting to take this course to first be familiar with programming concepts and C# syntax. Finally, I really think there ought to be a lot more quizzes, in addition to exercises, in order to both reinforce the knowledge that students are gaining as well as give them more small moments of success. As students complete small quizzes over small portions of material, they are better able to maintain and solidify the experience.

results.content:
I do apologize for leaving a negative review but the course is just missing crucial parts, I wouldnt consider it a complete course.

The first exercise really wound me up too because it was kind of like giving me 2 sticks and telling me to build a computer.

I had to go through the solution on github which I felt was also unclear and irritated me that we hadnt covered stuff in the course that we were expected to know beforehand. I would consider myself to have quite strong problem solving skills aswell but I still had issues.

I expect the odd problem in every course I take but the last straw for me was when I got to about lecture 25? When we add migration and I did this and it added a class for me, but the class only contained 2 methods; Up() and Down() and once i read through the Q&A, one of the guys said you should probably start again if you get this issue.

I work with C# code on a daily basis and I know there were some pre-requisites but I still feel this course needs some huge improvements.

I will return when the course is complete because I think the trainer is an awesome guy, I just don't think this particular course has been put together very well.

results.content:
There are a lot of moments in this course that feels like a fill in the blank test.  For example in exercise 1 of the course, we had to use bootstrap code to make a sleek looking table. He provided a pdf with the code that made this table but never explained where to put it or how to use it. 

When he covered the helper method return "view()". He never explained that when a model is placed within the parentheses it searches the view folder for a file that matches the name of the controller action. Not going into detail about this prevented me from moving on with the course in a quick manner. I had to figure this out by google searching. 

I would still say this course is better than watching youtube videos but it's not worth more than 10 dollars.

results.content:
Disclaimer: I had previous knowledge of ASP.NET MVC5 and already developed my first web app (with a fair amount of suffering, though).
Note that English is not my first language.

I'd like to highlight 3 things:

1. Very good explanations. 
2. Videos very respectful of my short attention span.
3. Good sound quality and Mosh is a good speaker.

1. I already took other courses on the subject but the pace has always been either too slow or too fast and the explanations have never been this concise and so on point.

2. As someone who gets bored real quick, this course has been fantastic. I already completed the third part of it in a couple of days and plan to finish it the next couple of weeks.

3. Good sound quality, enough said. Great Speaker. English is not my first language and I do not live in an English speaking country and I had no problem following this course. 

This course has helped me improve significantly my previous Web App and I hope to build in the future more robust and secure applications rapidly and with less suffering.

The instructor is very nice and friendly.
The examples and exercises are also good, because he shows it with a "Customer Example", but the exercises are built on "Movies", which are very similar. So you can work side by side.

But why the "bad" rating?

Because I was very frustrated, that the Git Repository he has, has classes which weren't in the course yet. 
For Example, right at the beginning, there are models and Controllers for Authentification, which are at the end of the Course.
So the git Repo doesn't match the video, and the git repo ist filled up with too much stuff.

results.content:
Mosh is my favorite instructor on Udemy. 

The course, while good, is not his best.  That said, Mosh sets a very high bar! 

This course could have been more thorough.  I wish it would have explored some aspects in greater depth, such as more advanced implementations of the Identity Framework, building robust user features, setting up SMTP clients for user confirmation by email, and using Entity Framework to create advanced entity relationships and tables in the database. 

It's almost as if this course demands a follow-up; perhaps "MVC Advanced".  And then this one can be the Beginner's course. 

That said, I did learn alot.  And it introduced me to topics that I was able to explore more in-depth with self-study.  

Also, Mosh indicates that his C# courses are prerequisite for this one.  I just want to reiterate that.  Students of this course must have good understanding of C# and general understanding of .NET to really work successfully through this one. 

Still recommend this course.  For sure!  Especially if taken after Mosh's three C# courses.

results.content:
Definitely a very good course but I expected something different according to the course title. Anyway, Mosh is a great instructor!
PROS:
1. very clear explanation - 
2. engaging - 
3. lot of guidelines - 
CONS:
1. too many topics not strictly related to MVC5 - 
2. sometimes the code shown in the following video (but written in the previous one) is not the same (so you get confused) - 
3. sometimes the instructor codes too much before compiling and testing so if you forget something it's a bit difficult to quickly find the error (you have to watch the entire video again)

results.content:
Mosh does a great job teaching MVC 5, showing pieces bit-by-bit and gives exercises similar to what he taught to see how well you can pick up the material. I recommend doing this exercise a little after watching the material to see if you remember what was taught and only rewatching when you get stuck.

The reason I didn't 5 star is because the course hasn't been updated in months and a whole visual studio version difference causes different defaults to be selected, which doesn't cause problems in the earlier lessons but, in later lessons, you wonder why something he's talking about is not there. Another problem is that newer updates to some plugins don't seem to work with his lectures so you may need to copy the plugin from github instead of downloading the latest from the official site. I may give 5 stars if this course updates but I imagine a course on Razor pages would occur in .NET core before that may happen.

Me esta costando mucho y no se muy bien si el siguiente ejericicio lo voy a completar por que es demasiado complicado, poco documentado y habla sobre "comentarios en el codigo", pero luego solo hay un comentario muy cutre que no ayuda en nada.
El contenido es muy bueno.
*Actualizacion*
Ahora estoy en el 50% del curso y ha hecho una mejora muy sustancial, eso no quita el hecho de que lo pase fatal al principio. Los ejercicios siguen siendo dificiles pero hay que estar atento y en 30 minutos los tienes hechos. En el gtihub, sube el codigo pero no esta ordenado, es decir, igual en github sale que lo primero que debes hacer es una cosa, pero probablemente, lo que tengas que hacer este mucho mas abajo.
Esta muy bien este curso.

results.content:
This is a really good course. If you've already done C# basic class and now want to get into real web development, this is a great stepping stone between basic c# and the new .NET Core stuff that you'll want to learn once you have this down. 

However, this course has some issues. Mosh is a nice guy, you can tell, and he is knowledgeable. However, he has taken some short cuts that make this course hard to follow. 

At the end of each section there is an practice part. To see if you did your practice session correctly, Mosh does not give you a video explanation of how he solved it - as most udemy courses do. Instead he just says "here's a git repo, you figure it out." So, if you're gonna take this, do the free git training udemy course first. You'll need to learn how to check out previous commits and then figure out for yourself where to look in his Github repo (all things you should learn anyways as a developer, so its not a total waste of time).  Even with that, you are basically better off just starting fresh at each section since you will have a hard time bringing your code into harmony with Mosh's. Additionally, he sometimes suddenly uses things to solve the exercise that he never taught you (he suddenly starts using Linq with no explanation or intro), making it kind of frustrating. 

My biggest complaint of all is when you buy this course, you get a nice message (automated) from Mosh saying, Please post me a good review, but, if you have a problem reach out to me first. Basically "only give me good reviews." When you reach out to Mosh via message, he does not respond. I waited a week to write this for his response just to be fair. He even says in one of the first videos "I don't have time to answer all your questions." The only way you will even be able to get past the first use of Database in this is by reading the Q&A that OTHER frustrated students have posted in order to make things work. Other instructors with much more in-depth courses have time to respond. I guess in a way, Mosh is teaching us to solve things ourselves, but a less-experienced programmer would probably have given up half way through this course.

Great as a starter course to .Net but Mosh really rushes a lot of concepts, this requires you do a lot background reading and researching as you are left with an inadequate explanation. 

Using Resharper was a really lazy way to make your course quicker to make. Again, more researching on the students part as the instructor wants to use his own shortcuts...

results.content:
I've spent about half a year trying to figure out ASP.Net MVC by myself and by reading various threads on StackOverflow etc. but kept losing focus, kept getting nowhere and eventually gave up. 
Being used to the simplicity of ASP.Net Web Pages in WebMatrix, the transition to ASP.Net MVC in Visual Studio seemed almost impossible, and I had no idea where to start.

Then I discovered Mosh's YouTube channel (including the first section of this course) and I felt like I'd struck gold! 
Mosh's calm and thorough way of explaining things in understandable words and metaphors made me buy the course almost instantly - and it's the best money I've ever spent on learning EVER!

Thank you for a fantastic in-depth and enlightening course, Mosh! I plan to rewatch this course several times and without a doubt dive into your other courses over time as well.

results.content:
About myself: I'm a technical person and a fast learner given a solid definitive resource. My background is in Physics and Computer Science. This course should be easy cakes for me.

Where it fails: This course is not self contained nor relevant anymore. Nor is the instructor focused. In the first module, he splits off into 5 directions instead of going over the correct way to implement MVC. You're going to find yourself rewatching the first section multiple times just to make sense on what the reference solution is. He literally spends the first 17 videos showing you the wrong way to do something over and over again.

That wouldn't be so bad if there were regular exercises to fill in the gaps. First exercise comes 17 videos in. And it's a train wreck, absolute train wreck. No skeleton code is provided. I spent 6 hours on what should've been a 20 minute exercise, with little progress. His solution file is a poorly managed github repo. And I want to emphasize the hundreds of comments on his github solution repo, of utterly baffled students.

Section 03 "Working with Data" is completely broken. Again, the instructor does not provide project files. Follow his instructions, and you are literally broken 37 seconds into that section. There are no workarounds. Since the course builds on one project, the rest of the course is rendered un-followable. The FAQ's do not address it either. Nor do you gain anything from just listening (he never explains what 'migrations' are).

This 'course' was an utter waste of time, and it has done more damage than good to my understanding. It is not worth $189, nor does it merit such a high rating. I strongly believe udemy should take this course down.

results.content:
I'd give this course alot higher rating however, when i came to the entity framework stage I feel like alot was missed out when it came to setting up entity framework. For me and many others, after following the videos I didn't have the right files in my project to use the entity framework. 

To fix this I had to restart the project (as proposed here: https://github.com/mosh-hamedani/vidly-mvc-5/commit/638c50c6bd42e356cef39706699429aff19be44e#commitcomment-21820511) to get entity framework to work. I don't see why the videos haven't been updated, that comment is from over 3 years ago. Fixing this common problem has wasted alot of my time

results.content:
Mosh is an incredible teacher, but when it comes to exercises.. All of a sudden we are supposed to know about a ton of new methods, let's take the first one for example.. Suddenly we are supposed to know about html.actionlink, IEnumerable etc. That's all fine if we got an explanation, but we dont. If you want a solution, you can browse a messy github rep.

I am 100% satisfied with his teaching, but i can't spend hours, trying to figure out what and why he has done what he has done.

results.content:
I understand that the training is for MVC specific, but at this point i'm not clear of:
1 - The difference between ActionResult and ViewResult.
2 - The IEnumerable setup for the functions "GetMovies" and GetCustomers.
3 - Not sure of the extra "fill ins" for the 1st exercise that are on GitHub, but were not explained (eg GetCustomers().SingleOrDefault(c => c.ID == Id))
What is that?
4 - Not sure I understand why we had to put RandomMovieViewModel into a separate folder than Models. I would have just gave it a name such as MovieToCustomersViewModel.cs and put it into Models.

Otherwise...very good course and everything else is explained very well.
I would recommend it.

results.content:
For the most part, I loved this course! The early sections are very useful and great for people with no exposure to ASP.NET; however, section 10 is riddled with bugs that aren't explained until future chapters in the section. I spent so much unnecessary time trying to debug code that was expected to work, when Mosh simply didn't explain the issue until later. This was especially frustrating when adding the search functionality with typeahead because Mosh did not give us a heads up that the dropdowns were not actually functioning during the sections we were writing them.

All of that being said, I absolutely still recommend this course. Mosh mostly does an excellent job explaining the details of the code and I truly learned a lot. Just be aware that sometimes you need to keep watching to solve some issues in the code.

results.content:
This course was absolutely outstanding!  It's fast-paced and very engaging.  As an older developer with an aging skill set that, I found this to be extremely valuable.  This is one of those topics that I've been avoiding for a while because it seemed way too complex for me to set aside time to learn it.  So... I've been stuck in a rut and developing code with out-dated techniques and technologies.  But after this course, I feel like I'm ready to take on projects using modern technologies and platforms.  I will be recommending this course to friends & co-workers and I plan to take Mosh's other courses because I'm so impressed with this one.

The only other thing that I'll say about it is that I do not consider this to be a beginner's course, even though it says it is.  I think it's far too in depth and covers too many topics for a beginner.  I've been developing for about 18 years and have been using ASP.NET since its inception, and this course was perfect for me.  You need to have a strong foundation in .NET and some other topics before taking this class.

Again... truly OUTSTANDING!

Mosh has done an excellent job by creating this course. He starts from the grass root level and slowly climbs to great heights. He covered everything which is essential to build a web application.

His talks on best practices are like grandmother's bag of wise advises. Its said that life is too short to make all the mistakes yourself - and I am sure following Mosh experience is indeed going to prevent lots of them. Here's a short rating:

Audio quality -                         * * * * *

Material covered -                   * * * * *

Pace (Speed) -                          * * * *

Hands on -                                * * * * *

Extra print material -              * * *
(like cheat sheet)

Real world applicability -       * * * * *
(like best practices)

GitHub code -                          * * * *

Overall - Its value for money. I learned a great deal from it. Thanks Mosh.

results.content: Great course! Money well spent, great value out of this course. And Mosh is a TEACHER! I'm sure he's a great programmer too, but he is definitely a TEACHER.  Other people may be great programmers,, but can't/don't know how to pass their knowledge to others. Not Mosh - he definitely has the teaching gene.  He's been great in getting you up to speed quickly in .NET MVC. He talks to you as if you're on the same level (i.e. just as smart as him), only uninformed about this specific subject matter (.NET MVC). I appreciate that.  Also like the fact that he says what "magic keys" he's pressing on the keyboard (i.e. shortcut keys) as he's typing the code and demonstrating features of Visual Studio.  The only negative I can say is the use of  Resharper tool (which he's a big fan of). Resharper adds stuff automatically for you in the code. But if you're a newbie, and don't have Resharper, you have to remember to do some things manually. To Mosh credit, he points out these things for you.. All in all, great course and I l already added to my cart other courses Mosh have that's related to this one.

results.content:
This course was awesome - great content!

I learned a lot during this course. I have a background in IT from the university in Romania . The only thing that I loved there was web development, C# , Azure and IOT. 

This course was a bliss for me, it helped me very much! Now, I use C#, asp.net , EF, MVC to create a web app for my diploma project! 

Mosh was entertaining, fun to watch (he made some very nice jokes -  I love his satire). I would like to have him helping me at explaining hard concepts associated with really simple examples from everyday life. 

Keep up the good work, Mosh! 

Best regards, 
David

results.content:
Excellent subject matter coverage. The pase is very fast, but the ability to replay the explanations and coding examples basically eliminates any problems with keeping up, unlike a live college lecture. A fair amount of additional research into external items may be needed, but that's all good.

Mosh is an excellent teacher, making the material easy to understand by not only demonstrating the "hows" but, also, illuminating the "whys." I'd rate the material presented at 4.5 stars, but Mosh's effective teaching style easily pushes it up to 5 stars. In fact, on the strength of this course alone I've purchased an additional five or six courses, most of them by Mosh.

results.content:
Mosh is a good tutor and I took a lot away from this course.

However, this course covers an enormous amount of material and is perhaps not so suitable for 'beginners'. I was under the assumption that this was a beginner's course, however it does assume a great deal of experience with ASP.NET and C# which I did not have. CS background and many years of front dev work just about got me through.

Other's reviews mentioned some of the later sections jumping around, either these have been fixed since those reviews or I didn't notice them. Either way the structure of the course was well thought out and adequately explained as you move through the course.

For my own sanity I may now checkout Mosh's intro to ASP.NET and C# courses! :)

results.content:
This course delivers on its name for being a complete ASP.NET MVC course.

Once completed, you'll know everything you need, to write any web application you'll encounter.

Going into the course, I had quite a few years experience with C# and HTML/CSS and some familiarity with ASP.NET and MVC concepts.  For me, the course content flowed at a steady and easy to follow pace.

I do feel a complete beginner might struggle to keep up with the pace, therefore it's important to take heed of the requirements for the course (C# & HTML/CSS familiarity) even though the course is marked as 'All Levels'.

Some topics felt a little rushed in explanation and I would have liked a bit more content on it (Data Transfer Objects & AutoMapper, Deploying Migrations, Client-Side scripting techniques as examples), but I understand these aren't key to ASP.NET MVC as a whole, they're simply supporting techniques / technologies.

Maybe some follow-up courses could cover these items in-depth as a complement to this excellent course.

Furthermore, I appreciated Mosh's honesty about techniques that are taught all over the web.  Giving clear merits why these techniques, although industry recommended, aren't always what they are promised to be. 

This perspective helped me look at articles and help pages differently when I'm searching online for a solution to a problem I'm having and makes me think twice before I implement something into my own projects.

Overall I'd recommend this course in a heartbeat to anyone wanting to learn all aspects of ASP.NET MVC.  

I went in with an understanding of ASP.NET and MVC concepts and I walked out with a clear view of how all the pieces fit together and how to approach new projects from an ASP.NET MVC point of view, and I've already put this knowledge into practice with a project that went live.

Excellent course presented by excellent instructor.

results.content:
This course is a nightmare to get through. The MVC components rely on a visual studio database the student is meant to create. 
The instructor gives an exercise, and the student needs to manipulate this database on their own. The odds are the student will make a mistake during the exercise, and if that mistake is in the database the teacher's solutions on github will not work with the student's databse. This can occur even if the student just handled some data slightly differently than the teacher.
So it becomes impossible to progress using the teacher's solutions and no clear route to debug the situation.

results.content:
Even though the course looks promising, my experience is that there's a LOT of places where you get stuck, like in example video 25, where you are to write the command "update-database" and you get an error. The instructor have made it unclear on how to fix this problem because instructor haven't encountered this, and it would benefit the students a lot if only the instructor have made it clear that you need to install some sort of program or modify some settings beforehand.

EDIT: I changed my rating to 5-stars since I can't blame these kinds of errors on the instructor. Having gone through most of this course I've gotten a more solid understanding of not only MVC, but also code optimization which has been a helpful tool in my current employment. So thanks, Mosh!

results.content:
It is great to be writing code all the way through the course.

The tutor is very clear as to why you take each step. I am yet to be overloaded with information or left wondering how something is working.

Each tutorial is bite size - there is a lot of content overall, but it is delivered at a suitable pace.

I have not installed ReSharper. The tutor sings its praises but does cater for students who have not installed it. Not having ReSharper has not been an issue for me.

I will be purchasing another course led by Mosh.

For reference, I have had some exposure to MVC in the past but nothing too serious and I don't believe it is necessary to have had exposure other than for additional context. If I were asked how certain MVC features worked (routing, for example), my response a month ago would have been, "Magic". Not anymore!

- Update -
I have finished the course. I still believe it is money very well spent as I have learned new things in every lecture. However, I do feel that the tutor was keen to finish this project as he came closer to the end. I felt like I was being talked to and instructed to "just watch this" more and got to code a little less, which is a bit of a shame in my opinion. After the halfway point, especially with the third party JavaScript libraries, I think a little more explanation as to how things work could have been given; I was left essentially copying code without really knowing how it worked. Compare that to the beginning of the course where Entity Framework is introduced, I felt I was given enough information not only to understand what was happening within our little application but also to encourage me to want to know more.

All that said, I have learned so much in this course that I think it is unjustified to lower my five star rating. The value of the course far exceeds the £15 I purchased it for. Great teacher and great content.

results.content:
Although the instructor knows how to express himself quite good, he has this tendency to add too many things at the same time without proper explanation. For the most of time, it's okay but there are times it would have helped a lot going a bit slower.

Another problem are the exercises which are a waste of pure time. I want to code side by side with the instructor as I memorize and learn what he tells me how things should be done. I will exercise when I start to develop my own web apps as I feel I'm ready to do so.

He really lost me when we moved on to Code First on section 3 and started to show me results on his Vidly app that was very different from mine, meaning I couldn't replicate his actions no more. I've went back and forth trying to see what I missed but I reached no conclusion. I just feel frustrated, considering this is a paid course.

results.content: I am a big fun of Mosh, his teaching style and I have completed a lot of his courses. However this course was a bit disappointing and I believe that Mosh could have done a match better job on that. It seems like he was in a rush not explaining why we should do certain things. We end up with an application that the home page is the standard MVC page. Second there is little covered for preventing attacks  using ajax and web APIs. Thirdly the course is a bit outdated in terms of some jquery plug ins but that is not very important as a bit of googling is enough to solve such problems. I will probably continue following Mosh's courses and I hope that this is the only one I personally did not like.

results.content:
Good teacher, questionable course content.

The teaching style is excellent, and the topics explained are well done. I also appreciate that the "intermediate" level is maintainted. The prerequisites are stated in overview and the teacher is consistent in not repeating basic concepts of the programming language, something that happens in other courses a lot.

However, the content is very lacking. "The complete ASP.NET MVC 5 course" is just misleading. This is not much more than just a walkthrough of developing a basic CRUD app. It's an introduction at best. After learning the Spring framework here on Udemy I must say I'm disappointed by the depth of this course, especially given the great reviews. 

Also, the course could do with an update to bring it up to current the development environment.
results.content_html:

The teaching style is excellent, and the topics explained are well done. I also appreciate that the "intermediate" level is maintainted. However, the content is very lacking. "The complete ASP.NET MVC 5 course" is just misleading. After learning the Spring framework here on Udemy I must say I'm disappointed by the depth of this course, especially given the great reviews.

Also, the course could do with an update to bring it up to current the development environment.

results.content: At first, I hated Mosh. His tutorials were taking over udemy in almost every topic I was trying to research. I was a noob and I thought he was teaching me bad practices by using the var keyword, along with using ReSharper on his first tutorial so I tried to stay away from him because I simply thought he was lazy. But in fact, those are actually best practices. I now enjoy his tutorials and I really like the way he says "let's get started". It makes me smile every time because I hear the excitement in his voice.

results.content: The course has the topics that I wanted, with projects at the end of the sections, it gives you a chance to use what you have learned, and to expand on the sections and think critically about what you are programming. I will say that the instructor consistently shows you irrelevant information. To clarify, he often shows you the "wrong way" and then the "right way", which I never agreed with throughout my education. He also spends time explaining the old ways of programming in earlier versions of ASP MVC. This is not terrible, but is again frustrating for someone who wants to learn more about the topic and to use it in their lives, and those tidbits will only be useful in the right circumstances when you come across legacy code - which you probably won't ever use, probably will not remember the syntax, and will most likely be looking through google if you ever came across something like that in the first place.

results.content:
Mosh did a great job being friendly and engaging and explaining why he chose different techniques over others. He touches on a lot of great things, but barely touches on a Many-to-Many Database relationship. I would have liked to have learned more about how those are completely set up, but that's just a personal preference in relation to a project I'm working on so take it with a grain of salt.

As a developer with a web programming and python background, this course made me much more comfortable with C# and it's complexity. Would love to see this updated for the changes in Visual Studio 2017, but most of the stuff is still extremely relevant.

results.content:
This course took me a while to complete because there is a lot of great content within. One of my favorite things about this course was the exercises that came with it. This is important in learning because if you do not put the ideas to use you will forget what you just learned.

The only thing I did not like about this course was the numerous times Mosh mentioned that he would not go into a topic because it was out of scope. That being said I do understand that he wouldn't be able to cover everything within one course. It was just quite a tease every time he said that it was up to me. 

I will have to go back into some of these lectures and see all the things he didn't cover so that I can learn about all the things. 

I did like that he provided his other material when applicable, but my only suggestion would be to provide some sort of link to further reading.

All that being said I disagreed with some of his implementations of classes, but I guess that is personal preference. I did struggle with some of the sections of the course, but hey ... that's programming for ya!

results.content:
Lots of quality information about ASP.NET MVC and useful code approaches. Generally a pretty decently-organized course, lots of details about many underlying approaches in ASP.NET MVC. Details about the historical development of the framework are great for understanding the advantages of different approaches (e.g. ViewDictionary vs. ViewBag vs. ViewModel).

On the flipside, the details can be dicey at times. Not all code works out of the box; you will have to do some Google searching to fix it. Version differences can cause some of this, though I was surprised to see quite the number of issues with the same major framework version and same IDE. There's some frustrating, unmaintainable spaghetti code used all around, and obvious refactors can be ignored until they become onerous.

Can also be sketchy in describing tradeoffs (e.g. no mention of the maintainability weaknesses in RouteCollection.MapMvcAttributeRoutes()), and can gloss over other issues in a way that suggests more confidence and knowledge than he actually seems to possess. For example, following sweeping, dubious claims about databases and database administration, he even proposes that verbose, clunky machine-generated code be passed to a DBA for handling. He also skips over some important details while redirecting to other courses he has published, which can be quite annoying, though Google is usually pretty forthright with the missing details.

Overall, it's a pretty solid course for handling ASP.NET MVC5. A few issues here and there, but it gets the job done. Viewers might wish to be wary of taking his offhand comments as gospel, though they shouldn't do that with anyone in the computing world.

Just been assigned a new project that uses asp.net mvc at work.  With 3 years of experience in C# and some experience with html, css, and nodejs, I thought I would spend a day on this course and try to make something simple at work as a test project.

It turns out to be much longer than a day and it should be.  This course is really reach in content and Mosh has a clear, intelligible voice.  But the pace is way too quick and require constant reviews.  It would also be nice for Mosh to write some comments in his code to explain what each part is doing.  I've seen enough uncommented code at work

results.content:
I started the course with zero ASP knowledge and enough C# to get by. It was hard at first, but it began to sink in after a couple of weeks.  It took me two months to complete it, and I put in 30 minutes to an hour most every day.

Mosh has a very good teaching style and is very friendly.  The code does have some bugs, though, and that is why I didn't give it 5 stars.  I thought he could have re-recorded the sections once the bugs were found. I could have spent less time if the bugs had been removed or if I had known a fix was coming later on in the videos.

I learned so much and I'm completely satisfied.  Exceeded my expectations!
