results.content:
This is a decent MVC course, but it lack some in-depth explainations. If you are completely new to MVC though, this is definitely good place to start.

Mosh is friendly and professional. He takes you through most of the crucial topics related to MVC. You get to create a nice, small app that could be use in video rental store. 

What I missed in this course were details and order. Some of the lessons are a bit chaotic, and Mosh happens to jump from topic to topic. I've worked with MVC before and I would like to know some of it's mechanics deeper. Instead I've got rather shallow insight in how MVC works. I would like this course to be longer - it's only 7.5 hours long and it tries to cover entire MVC - in my opinion it's far too fast.

I also didn't like the Deployment section - it's explained only in theory, and we don't get to really publish our app to see it run on some hosting provider.  I feel that I will still have to do plenty of research before I publish my app to public website.

So to sum up - it's a decent course to take if you would like to start working with MVC, but if you want to gain solid and deep understanding of this framework, it may not be enough. I think Mosh is a talented tutor, but he shall slow down a little and go deeper into details of framework mechanics.

Great Course! Covers Exactly what I'm interested in. With some basic c# knowledge (and more previous JS knowledge) I was able to really understand how C# ASP MVC works, and create some really cool stuff on my own.

Anyways, great course.

results.content: First of all, this is NOT a COMPLETE course. A lot of parts of the code that are important to be mentioned and explained in order to follow the course and understand what is happening, are not mentioned at all. The instructor says that the missing parts are explained in another course of his, so if we want the complete course we have to buy the other course too. Also, the course is outdated. I have to deal with errors because of the incompatible version of visual studio (the instuctor uses vs2013 and I use vs19) and I don't think that using the vs13 version is the solution to the problem. I bought this course in order to learn MVC and use it at my work in 2020, not to learn old things that are incompatible with the latest version. I recommend that the course should be updated asup.

results.content: This course was perfect.  The Vidly video rental store app built throughout the course is interesting and helpful.  The course uses Visual Studio 2013 but I was able to translate all of the material into Visual Studio 2019.  The only "half star" deduction is for the cause of out dated material.    The Postman Chrome extension used in Section 6 is a good example of technologies that have evolved significantly since Mosh first put this course together.   Navigating the new Postman app has very little in common with the look and operation of the old Chrome extension.  All in all though a really GREAT course!

results.content:
You will struggle.  There are many comments on this course discussing the same issues I have ran into.  Stuff just doesn't work for a variety of reasons.  Also the 2nd exercise throws stuff at you that was not even covered.  Lamda expressions, IEnumerable etc.  Granted those are C# and you need that for a pre-req, but why require that in the exercises when you don't even mention either word in the tutorial...

This class is mostly frustrating and a struggle.  I don't think I will ever finish it.

results.content: The problem with this course is not what is taught, but HOW it is taught. Up until the exercises everything is clear and consise. However, the instructor does not go through the exercises like he does in lectures. Instead, he post the solution on github, which is great, but it would be nice to see how certain code is generated. I was able to debug, due to my coding experience & stack overflow, but so many issues could've been easily resolved if the instructor walked through the exercises after allowing the student to attempt. Sometime the code on github is not presented in the order that code was generated in. Therefore, you are often caught skipping over steps that could've been pivotal to your application. In turn, this leads to spending an hour on debugging a problem that could've easily been avoided. Again, the information taught is very helpful, but the instructor doesnt seem interested and getting you to the final steps as I would like. Many of the problems are often on the github thread or in the questions section of the course. Some are answered. Some aren't.

results.content:
STUDENT BEWARE!! 
 You WILL NEED to install ReSharper to adequately follow this course. 
 Although I like the course so far, Mosh refers a lot to the "ReSharper" software which is an extra purchase (and somewhat expensive) outside of Visual Studio.  He should focus more on using VS and the free available packages then on a 3rd party software package that must be purchased.  It sounds almost as if he's a spokesperson for the software.
EDIT:  The further I got into this course, the more I found that the instructor is very much relying on resharper to make this webapp.  A pre-requisite for this course should be to have resharper installed.  If it did have this, I wouldn't have purchased the course.  The student will find themselves confused and wondering how things got done when it was the magic of resharper doing it for Mosh.
EDIT AGAIN:  I got almost halfway through this course and found that much has changed from when this was created to when I viewed this course.  And no offense to the teacher assistant, but all he does, if you have a question regarding the course, is tell you to check your code via github.  Mosh does not monitor this course or its questions.  Sadly I wasted $13 on it, whereas it's not a big deal, I did learn some things, but I just can't complete the course.  Hard as I try, I run into more & more issues\questions with each passing lecture that I force myself on to the next lecture hoping it will get better.  Unfortunately it does not.
The course needs serious updating which I don't think will happen.  
Buyer beware with this course.  I do not recommend it, at all.

results.content:
Mosh is a great instructor, but the course is rather outdated, so you have to find a lot of fixes around to get be able to progress. The starting pacing is a bit confusing, because many of the exercises you have to find the answer on his github and there's no code review and many times his solutions are kinda different than what he taught you through the curse. But towards the middle and the end the pacing gets better and you be able to progress through the curse without further problems. One note is that all the errors and outdated stuff that needs solution can be found in the Q&A session of the course by newer students.
My suggestion is to only update the course with the parts that are broken so that new students can zap through it without a problem.

results.content: The course started off really strong. I learned a lot about the MVC structure and how it all fits into the development cycle. The only downside to this class is it is outdated, considering it was filmed in 2016 and last edited in 2018. There are quite  few spots, especially towards the end where code does not work and neither the teacher or assistant provide an answer. The community on github have filled in a lot of blanks on where his code goes wrong, but it would be nice if it were updated to reflect problems found.

results.content: Really outdated course, and no updates are provided to help you where programs are not available or options are changed. You can go to the comments section, but it appears the instructor does not care about giving any answers himself. For example, if you do not know about one option that has changed in Visual Studio 2019 (the course was made with an older version) then when you run into the entity framework section you will need to restart the project and migrate your work into an entirely different solution. Additionally some tools linked don't exist in the same form as they used and/or are outdated. With that said, the instructor style I do like, it's just a shame it's so outdated now.

results.content:
Awesome course, as expected of Mosh. Very in-depth explanations, real-world applicable scenarios, and a very nice set of exercises make learning this topic (and any topic, really) very engaging and fun, as well as hard to forget.

Mosh is a great instructor, and teaches a whole lot of best practices, comparing even MSDN examples (which many people take as law) to real, tested, much better examples.

Definitely a great course, makes learning either MVC or WebAPI extremely simple, but at the same time, greatly in-depth, without being overwhelming.. something quite hard to achieve!

Will definitely keep an eye out for future courses (like the architectural one promised somewhere near the end) as I really admire Mosh's principles and practices.

results.content:
Mosh is a really good teacher. He explains the concepts well and works at a really even pace. Easy enough to follow (with the occasional pause of the lecture) but it doesn't take forever to get through a section. His knowledge of the subject matter is (for the most part) very apparent and there is no doubt in my mind that he's a very capable software engineer.

My biggest criticism is he's occasionally inconsistent with what he preaches as best practice. For example he cautions often against "magic" strings and numbers (for good reason), but then essentially duplicates models and views to tackle some really basic tasks. I'm no expert, but I can already tell that it's bad practice. I know Microsoft isn't always flawless in their architecture but I am certain they have built in better ways to handle some of these things.

I'm curious if Mosh or one of his TAs could review some of the criticisms I've left in the Q&As. If they can prove me wrong, or revise the materials to better approach these items then I will gladly edit my review accordingly.

results.content:
Edit: I was able to figure out the issues. Would've still liked it if I at least had an answer back from the initial question I had. Good information, but I'm deducting a star because of the lack of a response to any questions.

Edit 2: The instructor also tends to blast through the videos at mach speed. It tends to make understanding what he's trying to teach a little problematic. He is also not really going in depth with anything, partially, but not enough for anything to really stick (Attribute Routing is one case where it was so quickly explained that I tried to implement it and failed miserably). If he managed to slow it down and give more in depth explanations, it would help out a lot in understanding what he's trying to teach.

Edit 3: And this turned out worse. Way to rip people off. So at the end of each section, he has you to review via modifying/editing a page....Then not only NOT give you any actual demonstration on how to do something (hello route attribute passing), but instead of giving a video explaining why he did what he did he shallowly redirects you to his GitHub page! Brilliant "teaching" methods. I'm going to officially block him and try to find an instructor who actually has his stuff together. This guy's a joke.

results.content:
Extremely hard to follow in certain parts and instructor does not provide full solutions to exercises. He states they can be found on his GitHub, but his files on GitHub look completely different than from what you are currently working on in the project. So if you want to try and follow along with what he is doing it's near impossible. Had to stop the course 35% of the way through because I don't know what files he is talking about half the time because we never created them in the course he is just assuming that you had the same mindset as him during the exercises. He also uses some code in his solutions that he never explains during the course, exercises should be strictly related to content he has covered during the course. The exercise solutions should have their own video where he goes over his mindset and why he made the decisions he did or at least the finished files after each section and not a GitHub repo that does not help at all because the project is already completed up there and do not match the current exercise you are working on.

I would not recommend this course for beginners. Bought a book off Amazon and it's leaps and bounds more clear.

I love the idea of code challenges, but I struggle so much just getting to the starting point.  I would be nice if there's a starting project point so that student can use that to complete the exercise, also, having a code review video or solution video would be perfect.  I gave up on the exercise after first lecture because I was spending too much time setting it up (I run into various obsticles) and spent half to a day gettting it ready.  Just too much time wasted.  Having test questions at the end of each section would be nice so that it can really test your knowledge.  With those in place, I would have given it a 5 stars.

results.content: This has been one of the top courses I have done on Udemy. I have recently switched to working in ASP.NET MVC and didn't have time to learn everything myself. This course covers a broad amount of mvc and the different aspects. It has given me a firm foundation of working in this environment. The lecturer doesn't reply that much to questions but he does explain a lot of things well. If you get stuck, its really worth putting in the time to discover what went wrong yourself, because in reality the problems can become more complex and its good practice to get that research skill going since its such an important part of development in general.

Decent voice and very intelligent man but there is not enough walkthrough on how things are done. The exercises themselves are a real pain since there is a huge mistep in not making a video on how to do  them. Looking at his git page for answers doesn't tell the whole story.

Informative but overall disappointing for a new comer like me who is not very experienced with coding. This course will be for you if you are already an established coder. I found this course a bit more helpful than the free ones available on the net.

2,5/5 for a beginner but probably a 4/5 if you are versed in the subject.

Also, the lecturers over reliance on Resharper is annoying.

results.content:
Mosh is a fantastic instructor who explains things clearly and concisely rather than rambling on about empty nonsense.

This course is extremely thorough and helpful. This course has created so many "aha!" moments for me, it's incredible! Highly recommended. You won't just learn how to do this stuff, you'll learn how to do it the RIGHT way. You will definitely be challenged and you will have to work through some things, but that is what coding is all about! Mosh truly goes above and beyond to explain how you can make a NICE, modern application with MVC rather than only showing you the basics of how MVC works. You also get an Entity Framework primer but for a more in-depth EF intro, get his separate EF course. Looking forward to more from Mosh!

Overall the course was good, instructor was excellent, decent response time for Q&A. 

But there are some issues for me.
1. The content is outdated,  old visual studio and different default settings when starting a project. Fixing it after following the class for a bit, just takes too much time.

2. Even though there is some information about preparing app for release. There is no training on actual deployment of the application and database to a server.

results.content:
While the content in itself is not bad, the amount of code changes done off-tape is really frustrating.

Project setup is explained poorly and the way the instructor presents the exercises is utter nonsense.
There's no special lecture that goes over the exercises and if something is not working as intended, the student is supposed to browse the github repo to find answers there.
And this is by design. I have no idea why that choice was made and this is the main reason for such low score.

results.content:
It’s getting a little better. The use of third party products is a bad idea because those products change, when trying to figure out a problem you shouldn’t have to figure out if you made a mistake or is a versioning problem with the third party software.

More importantly when discussing WebApi Controllers the author should comment on how it why we have both WebApi controllers and non WebApi controllers. I suspect he’ll explain why we have both or how the non WebApi controllers are affected later. But we shouldn’t have to wait because it makes things confusing.

results.content:
Many important concepts are mentioned quickly and without supporting detail. 

But by far the worst thing about this course is that it is OUTDATED, leading to many frustrating hours searching for workarounds/checking Q+A. 

It's simply inexcusable that Mosh and the Support staff have STILL not added even simple overviews of the workarounds required (and in most cases provided by people paying for the course!). Encountering these issues brings learning to a complete stop. 

There is even a fundamental project-restarting setup requirement that's missed out. This is mentioned in one of the teaching staff's Q+A responses where he states that He and Mosh will get round to updating the course content. This was TWO YEARS ago.

The course is generally great, but it's ridiculous that these issues are left to paying Customers to resolve.

results.content: Fantastic course, but some important changes in the tech and tools used since the recordings were made can cause headaches later in the course, when they become apparent. Realistically, these should be pointed out earlier rather than later so that students new to the material will not have to search out solutions to problems which don't occur in the videos. At the present moment it is pivotal that students look at the Q&A's for each lecture BEFORE MOVING ON. In particular, they should ensure that they manually enable user authentication when they create their projects (second or third lecture), or they'll potentially have to restart once they hit the code-first workflow portions. Outside of this, the course is absolutely worth the money. Thanks Mosh.

Up to beginning "chapter 3"/using data, so far I am learning new things (MVC seems like a different world from plan old ASP.NET web site design). 

The exercise for "chapter 2" seemed to involve needing more overall experience than was suggested for this course, I did get it work (whether it's 100% ideal is another story) but it required looking at Q&A and picking up concepts not covered in the course and slightly more than just copy and pasting. If "that's life" when it comes to learning courses I sort of get it - just wished it would be mentioned more.

Still hoping to learn more!

results.content:
Clear, concise course. Motivating instructor! I learned a lot in 2½ days.
Two minor issues IMHO: The Entity Framework tend to be a bit off-topic. However, it the real world, some kind of database access layer will obviously be needed. But, in 2017, I think maybe a noSQL db would be simpler and keep the focus more on ASP .NET MVC.
Also, it seems a little outdated to use a video rental shop as the "real world" example in 2017 ;-) But of course it's just an example that everyone (older than, say, 25 years ;-) can understand.

results.content:
The first part of this course started off great.  As a true beginner (I'm experienced with JavaScript but not at all with C#/ASP.Net) I felt like I was understanding the concepts and learning how to put together a project.  Midway through the course I feel like the instructor's explanations became too quick and not detailed enough.  I was able to do what he did, but not understand why I was doing it.  The exercises were good, but he doesn't show you how to solve them; you're expected to go to his github and look up the solutions.

Lastly, he uses a lot of shortcuts with ReSharper which is a $300 product.  If you've never used it before you can get a 30-day free trial, but if that expires there will be a few times where he uses a shortcut via ReSharper that you'll have to do manually.

results.content:
I really found this course useful, the instructor explained everything that a web app should have, do and why, even though it was not always explained in detail, it was pretty much well described.
Now, in order to be consequent with my rating, I have to aware others, that the instructor said that this was for beginners and for someone who is starting in the ASP.NET MVC world, it can be very frustrating and can feel very lost sometimes. I also have to mention that I am also a student from his other course (EntityFramework).
I can understand that the purpose of the instructor is to market his courses, but for me it felt like (and this is my personal opinion) he always tried to engage students as clients, which he shouldn't, he must teach, explain and try to be as clear as possible. Sometimes he should answer students questions, to become a real teacher, not walking them thru the exact solution, but to help how.
Beginners!, stay focus, do your own research, what you see in this course is purely the essential and sometimes it can get mixed with more complex situations, there is where you have to pay attention and do your own research.

For all instructors, please move on from the typical solutions: Video Rentals and Car Rentals, reality gives you more than just 90's college solutions. Use real scenarios please!!

In the section 2 exercise there was a moment where we had to tweak vidly.csproj file. There It had no explanation of why we need to apply such settings. 
After a workaround I wasn't able to access Index.cshtml of Customers/Movies Views. File not found error was put up by VS. Infact couldn't open any view in those folder until I replaced them with new razor view with same name. 

I expect Mosh to give a fast complete solution before ending any section. that way it would be time saving. Everyone is passionate to discover solution but providing yours would help us to pick up where we've left stuck.

results.content:
I loved this course. The value of this course is immediately apparent after just the first few lectures. Mosh does a great job explaining and the way the course is set up is very well done. 

I was getting so frustrated of trying to piece together knowledge of ASP MVC from tutorials and MSFT docs - this is exactly what I was looking for. I would advise doing the Contoso University tutorial off the microsoft website first so you have some understanding of ASP MVC because while Mosh is very detailed, the pace of the course is fast. Thats a good thing because you can always go back and gain deeper understanding. 

As for Mosh's style of teaching, I really liked how he is straightforward, and not trying to overdo things with energy and jokes, although I did laugh quite a bit. His accent is very easy to understand. 

In the end, it took me about 60 days to get through it all. After I got to around part 8, I started my own application and used his for reference - then went ahead and completed it.

Thank you Mosh, you really earned my $12 or whatever I spent aha
results.content_html:
I loved this course. The value of this course is immediately apparent after just the first few lectures. Mosh does a great job explaining and the way the course is set up is very well done.

I was getting so frustrated of trying to piece together knowledge of ASP MVC from tutorials and MSFT docs - this is exactly what I was looking for. I would advise doing the Contoso University tutorial off the microsoft website first so you have some understanding of ASP MVC because while Mosh is very detailed, the pace of the course is fast. Thats a good thing because you can always go back and gain deeper understanding.

As for Mosh's style of teaching, I really liked how he is straightforward, and not trying to overdo things with energy and jokes, although I did laugh quite a bit. His accent is very easy to understand.

In the end, it took me about 60 days to get through it all. After I got to around part 8, I started my own application and used his for reference - then went ahead and completed it.

Thank you Mosh, you really earned my $12 or whatever I spent aha

Could not go through the course because the course outdated and does not work in VS2017, also the instructor is skipping major steps which completely bogs students who are not familiar with that subject. He is assuming that because he has another course on udemy (Entity Framework) it is ok to skip basic principles of EF on this course.   

I recommend for the instructor to go step by step and explain each step he is taking, don't just assume the student just knows.

Also, advise to him to read all the Q&A comments and update his course according to those feedbacks.

It would be good to list what configuration and VS version to use at the beginning of the course. So, students don't have to recreate the whole project in mid course because it turned out that an older version of VS needs to be used.

results.content:
UPDATE: I am adding .5 star back. I always go back to this course for reference whenever I have a question with a project I'm building. Honestly, Mosh explains everything so concisely and in such an easily understood manner that I wish I could ingrain everything this course in my head.          
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The material is explained in clear detail and in an extremely intuitive manner. The techniques learned are immediately applicable and their uses immediately apparent. The exercises are engaging and require critical thought and true "digestion" of the lecture material. ONE BIG STAR KNOCKED OFF because I think there should be solution walkthrough videos, not just links to the solution repo on Github. For people learning to program and struggling to come up with code solutions, it is important and helpful for someone who has had a lot of experience programming to explain their thought process. The learner can then incorporate this thought process into their own projects. If Mosh had solution walkthroughs, this would've been a knock-out perfect course.

response.content: Thank you for your feedback. I definitely take your suggestion onboard for future courses.
response.content_html: Thank you for your feedback. I definitely take your suggestion onboard for future courses.

results.content: Instructor left out key information that makes the course almost impossible to follow without spending hours looking through GitHub comments to fill the gaps he left. Eventually I had to just give up on following along on my own and just watch the course. The only responses from Mosh's assistant in the Q&A is him posting the final solution from GitHub and expecting people who are just starting the course to find what they need by viewing the final product. Some people in the chat try to defend Mosh's methods by saying that Mosh is trying to get you to learn the information on your own. If I wanted to go to YouTube or GitHub to learn the things Mosh doesn't cover then I would have never paid for this course. You are better off just not paying for this course and learning it on your own.

results.content: Great explanations and introduction to MVC!  Great transition from MVC to Web API.  Always wondered what all that Web API stuff was.  Definately a LOT of material and a LOT of steps to create a MVC/Web API/RESTful application.  I am going to review some content again from my notes, attempt to create an application on my own via the concepts from this course and probably will end up watching this course again.  There are just SOOO many steps and things to keep track of.  I miss Silverlight as it was pretty straightforward and it just looked good!
results.content_html: Great explanations and introduction to MVC! Great transition from MVC to Web API. Always wondered what all that Web API stuff was. Definately a LOT of material and a LOT of steps to create a MVC/Web API/RESTful application. I am going to review some content again from my notes, attempt to create an application on my own via the concepts from this course and probably will end up watching this course again. There are just SOOO many steps and things to keep track of. I miss Silverlight as it was pretty straightforward and it just looked good!

results.content: This instructor has a very flawed course, which is a shame as I find him a very good teacher. Too many times I have had to go hunting for  unmentioned frameworks or code. At first it felt good to to self research but it soon become impossible for me to continue with the course. I would see other students with the same criticisms and asking the same questions. With such a variety of solutions (that others provided, NOT the instructor) appearing, it was difficult to know what to apply to my case as the project got more in depth. I'm learning this for a job and EVERY co-worker has commented on their frustration when learning from Mosh on this particular course. Thankfully they have pointed me towards other resources which I will now use.

results.content:
Extremely clear presentation. I can easily follow the coding sessions. The mastery of the instructor in using Visual Studio is inspiring! Introducing helper libraries like AutoMapper is unique among other similar courses (I didn't know about AutoMapper before taking this course and my mapping code normally exceeds 1000 lines!).
I hope that Mosh creates more Advanced courses on ASP.NET Web API 2 and dig deeper into topics like ASP.NET Infrastructure, OWIN, DI, Architectural concerns, Performance, OAuth and ....
Thank you Mosh for great work!

* Publish to Azure

results.content: Mosh is a great instructor and his way of explaining things makes the whole learning process very exciting and you never feel bored. The only reason I gave 4.5 stars to this course is because I was expecting all MVC details in this course  as the course named as "Complete ASP.NET MVC 5". There are few small things in some concepts which I found were missing. But having said that there are a lot of extra tools and techniques which you will get to learn in addition here which you will not get in other courses. But definitely this course is one of the best and Mosh is a great teacher. I have also taken his Becoming a Fullstack Developer Series in Pluralsight and learned a lot.

There are few small things in some concepts which I found were missing. I can relate to the "horse drawing" analogy, which following can easily draw basics all of a sudden become a complicated horse. Which seemed like a discourse.

Suggestion: there should be a "Support" e-mail every time someone enrolls in a class. I know that you have mentioned how can you support thousands of enrollees, but I think it should be implemented.

results.content:
This course was really educational and practical.  It is also quite complete and gave me more than I expected.  The API information, entity framework and design tips along the way were all very helpful.

I can tell the instructor is 'the real deal' and knows his subject and understands it well enough to be able to actually relay his years of experience in a way that makes sense to me as a student.   

I highly recommend this course for learning MVC.  All code examples are on GitHub -- just make sure to read other students comments in both the GitHub and Udemy site to get a full experience and help you get over places where you might get stuck.  Good Stuff!
results.content_html:

results.content:
First of all, I like Mosh's voice so that really helps. It isn't monotonous and has a relaxed quality to it - this guy could probably make money making relaxation tapes. The really nice part of the course though is the way he explains things, he always tries to relate things to real-world situations and to his experiences as a developer. His way of explaining things is easy to understand that even first-time programmers can get it. Finally, the course is well designed. The progression and escalation is good and you won't find yourself stuck on a lesson wondering how you could proceed to the next.

Congratulations and thank you. Keep up the good work.

results.content:
Mosh,
Thank you for helping me know ASP.NET MVC better and showing me lots of useful tools.
If you don’t mind, I have some recommendations and some concerns for you.
1.	Could you please give backend explanation for key technology? For example, MemberType is not only for saving type text purpose, it can make sure that MemberTypeID can be treated as foreign key after I tried to change the name. Please check JeremyBytes on youtube for better backend explanations. Letting student know the reason is more important than knowing how to do it.

2.	At beginning, you used server post most time and at end you use Ajax most time. According to OOP, I believe Ajax would be very hard for maintenance in future since
a.	javacript is object language, which is not object oriented language
b.	debugging is not easy  (unless you have a good debug way?)
What is basic principle to use ajax or server post? Should both be used at same time? Or Ajax should be used all the time?
3.	During you course, you said jquery datatable could not handle big dataset and you will give explanation later, did I miss it?
 
4.	Code layout is only on demo level, for example, all exception and warning information could be organized to OOP level?

5.	Could you please give several professional Theme design for a website? Or analyze a modern bootstrap theme?For example, ajax area, search bar area, category bar area etc. 

Sorry to leave some many comments. I really like to use your course in the real world!
Thanks again,
Shenyi
results.content_html:
Mosh,
Thank you for helping me know ASP.NET MVC better and showing me lots of useful tools.
If you don’t mind, I have some recommendations and some concerns for you.
1. Could you please give backend explanation for key technology? For example, MemberType is not only for saving type text purpose, it can make sure that MemberTypeID can be treated as foreign key after I tried to change the name. Please check JeremyBytes on youtube for better backend explanations. Letting student know the reason is more important than knowing how to do it.

2. At beginning, you used server post most time and at end you use Ajax most time. According to OOP, I believe Ajax would be very hard for maintenance in future since
a. javacript is object language, which is not object oriented language
b. debugging is not easy (unless you have a good debug way?)
What is basic principle to use ajax or server post? Should both be used at same time? Or Ajax should be used all the time?
3. During you course, you said jquery datatable could not handle big dataset and you will give explanation later, did I miss it?

4. Code layout is only on demo level, for example, all exception and warning information could be organized to OOP level?

5. Could you please give several professional Theme design for a website? Or analyze a modern bootstrap theme?For example, ajax area, search bar area, category bar area etc.

Sorry to leave some many comments. I really like to use your course in the real world!
Thanks again,
Shenyi

results.content:
If you are using Visual Studio 2017 this is not going to be the program for you to use.  The Entity Framework content starting in the 3rd Module does not work as advertised.  For me I do not want to take the time to learn an older version that is not compatible with newer versions.

On the other side if you have an older version like Visual Studio 2015  and want to learn MVC 5 Mosh is a great instructor providing details and concepts in an easy to use and understand way.

I found myself often pausing the video, typing the code, then going back to listen why, and what the code was actually doing.

results.content: Teaching style of the instructor is very bad. Most of the new concepts are not well explained (or even worse, they are not explained at all) I had difficulties to follow changes made in codes and transitions between class definitions. The reason for this is that even if the course is "for everyone even with no previous knowledge about MVC", the instructor seems to assume students already know some concepts. Further, some of the concepts are taught shallowly. (e.g. Authentication, Web API's etc.). Most importantly, there is no detailed explanation/video about any of the assigned exercises and it is a very bad idea to clone each solution from github repository and try to understand the code by alone. Since all videos are cumulatively proceeded based on the solutions of the instructor, it is very hard to follow the code. Please include a dedicated video for each exercise so that following a right approach to a specific problem can be easier.

results.content: So far this have been an excellent course. Because web development is new to me (I'm familiar with advanced C#, so it's not hard or a problem, I just need to make sure I'll remember it), I often need to watch and reset the code that lectures dictated me to write so I can do it again multiple times to let it really sink in and also do the exercise a few times. So that makes me slow to finish this. Nonetheless I learned alot of cool stuff and I really like it. The secret to really master it is in repeating lectures untill the theory is unthinking habit and then do the exercise without cheating or getting help.

results.content:
The instructor knows his stuff and the presentation of what was there was very clear but there were annoyances unfortunately. 

1) Resharper (no criticism intended of this product) use just got in the way and teaching keyboard shortcuts is not appropriate when trying to learn the basics. I take the instructors point about professional use but we are not there yet. 

2) A more significant problem though is the exercises or rather the lack of video solution walkthroughs. Instead you are directed to github. This is bad for a number of reasons:

a) there is no guidance on the correct solution and we make use of these as the course builds, 
b) it misses an opportunity to reinforce the concepts,
c) github saves all file changes including those that are managed by visual studio itself (e.g. project file),
d) the QA spills over onto github.

 The Web API piece was too half hearted and we wasted time returning exceptions and refactoring and using automapper. RESTful responses and IHttpActionResult implementation wasn't explained for all of CRUD nor were the return types. Fundamental omission. This was left to us as an exercise! 

There is so much information in the course and the best practices discussions makes it worthwhile . The exercises are well thought out and may well throw you curve balls but that is as much to do with the nature of Asp.net MVC and EF. Just needs more guidance and much tighter focus.

results.content: This is a meisterwerk of on-line instruction. Everything worked just as it was supposed to. My team and I all took this course together, and then used that knowledge to build a medium-sized MVC application in just four weeks. We used Entity Framework code-first. Our next app will be an AngularJS SPA with MVC API providing the data access. We have lifted our little company into modern web development thanks to this course.

results.content:
Clear concepts, awesome explanation, provides alternative ways of doing something with pros and cons - very useful, will teach you the best and most secure ways to write and implement frameworks and technology efficiently by explaining different scenarios for clarity and the reason behind it - something that very few instructors here on Udemy preach. If and when you start learning ASP.NET just by yourself through official Microsoft tutorials, you'll realize that there are too many ways to start learning each topic and it will get really overwhelming real quick whereas this course eases you into ASP.NET by slowly and gradually introducing you to the topics one by one that are really important, used in the industry as a standard and a must for a developer to know if you'll be working with the stack. This will help you in understanding the framework cohesively and easily. 

Once you've completed this course, I would suggest everyone to take Mosh's Pluralsight courses on ASP.NET further strengthen your understanding.

results.content: I'm writing this review after completing half of section 3 as well as sections 1 and 2. Mosh has an exercise in section 2 which he then builds upon in section 3. The only problem? He doesn't explain or even show the code to his solution at all. He simply says to look at his github. There is no link to his github as far as I can see (if I'm wrong please correct me and I will edit this review) and the only way I found it was by googling his name and the word github and getting lucky that it showed up. Furthermore, once you are on his github you will notice that he did not make projects for each of the exercises, he has a single project for this whole course, so unless you are knowledgeable enough on github to know to dig through his commit history, you can't even view the solution code. The course was great up until this point, but this was just too lazy of Mosh to give a 4 or 5 star rating.

results.content:
It's one of the best ASP.NET MVC course.
I had intermediate knowledge of the MVC and I'm a seasoned ASP.NET Web Forms developer. Mosh has an Software Engineer attitude and that's very important. Knowing what to do and why to do is very important. 'code monkey' mind and 'software engineer' mind are different things.
It's an 2-year-old lesson, and the current version of Visual Studio is 2017. So, there could be a little differences, but I just found them with a few google searches. Anyway, its a good course, and I recommend it :)
Also, bought his 'The complete Angular Course' and completed half of it.
Now, I will also finish his 'Unit Testing' and 'Entity Framework' courses (bought them as well :) )
I loved his education style.
I'll also buy your 'Node js' course, when it's available on the Udemy :)
Anyway, thanks for the great course :)
( 5 stars ) to the course :)
*****

results.content:
ASP.NET MVC has been a completely impenetrable mess of a language, as far as I'm concerned. I've been in two full Udemy classes before this one to try to make sense of it. Each time the lessons are specific to a narrow result, which means real-world application is almost non-existent since deviating from exactly what the instructor wrote causes a complete crash.

Mosh does it again. Only 30% in, and I'm having a 'aHA!' moment with every chapter. I'll keep my head down and update this review if my perception changes, but so far, so so good.

results.content:
It's a slow start, especially if you're a little shaky on C# or OOP in general, but with some work into it you will cover quite a bit of ground.

However a lot of keyboard shortcuts or small changes have occurred since Visual Studios 2017 was released and there is a bit of googling that has to be done to figure things out. Also, there is a large reliance on ReSharper which is admittedly a very strong program, but some may not want to sign up for the trial or learn with ReSharper in general.

results.content:
The course did provide instruction on coding/use of MVC but unfortunately it digressed into topics, which are related to development, are not necessarily related to MVC programming.  i.e.: Facebook authorization; Optimization; Error Logging.  Had he focussed on ASP.NET MVC, the course could be shorter.  By adding these other topics explanations became incomplete and the phrase "... not in scope of this course..." was often used.  If it isn't in scope, why introduce the topic?

The fact that the course is 2 years old doesn't help since some processes have changed (i.e.: how Facebook authorization is performed in the course is no longer applicable).  Other Udemy instructors have updated their included how to incorporate current changes.

I also found that the github repository that the student is to use for comparing exercises sometimes did not match the specific exercise.  It could contain code that was introduced in subsequent lessons.
results.content_html:

results.content: I think Mosh is a great instructor and like his presentation style as well as his outline of the big topic, MVC in this case.  I would caution others that following his examples step by step can lead to some mistakes on the student's part.  For example, I had a leftover @model statement specifying the random movie view model, and when I first tried to do the section 2 exercise, I got a blizzard of errors that were hard to understand.  He should give people a basic setup or send-off for exercises with a "don't forget" piece of advice or two.  That would not compromise the challenge that he wants the student to face.

I really enjoy the way the content is delivered and taught. I found there were times when I had to comb through his Github to figure out what was wrong with my code but I took this as a good learning curve and learnt a little more by troubleshooting myself. 

I did not enjoy the shameless self promotion of his other courses by not including information on certain topics because he does not want to "waste the time of students who have already watched the courses". The beauty of online applications is those students can just skip ahead while watching the video.

results.content:
The good:
*For the most part, Mosh has a great teaching style.
*You will learn the practical basics of setting up a web app with MVC design with coding and a fair amount of simple visuals.
*You get an understanding of work flow from user case to implementation and deployment.
*You will hear about some topics worth further investigation and research as well as suggested best practices and counter-points.
*Though the video length is only ~7 hours, you will likely spend ~30 - 40 hours building the app and doing exercises.

The bad:
*The course has failed to update to newer versions of supporting frameworks leaving the student to copy information off github repository.
*Helpful hint videos have failed to be inserted. Example: VS 2019 ASP.NET Web App launches with no authentication method as default.  If you don't know to select it at project creation you will have to start over.
*You will hear about a paid IDE plugin mentioned countless times, and it does waste time as that will not be available for everyone regardless of it's effectiveness.
*Expect responses to questions to take 3 days or more.  However, the most common questions are answered already in the comments or on github comments.

Summary:
It's still a worthwhile course, but I would only recommend this course as a supplement to other courses as there is some really good content you will unlikely see other places.  You'll have to deal with some of the annoyances I listed in "the bad", but you can consider practice in dealing with challenges at work.  Possibly it's also a great course for someone with some programming experience but would like a quick take off with web applications (i.e. the person is experience mostly on one end of the stack).

results.content: Good coverage of the subject as a whole, but feels patchy in some areas and rushed in others. The lack of discussion page monitoring may be a problem, although to be fair Mosh does explicitly explain that you're not paying for that type of support from him. The follow up course, which will "definitely be out in [...] 2016" has yet to materialise (couldn't find it in a search). I'm assuming this is just stuck in the pipe though and will be out soon enough. But those are mostly niggles, and the course serves as a good introduction.

results.content: This course suffers from the instructor being too brief in his explanation of code, or adding code showing another way of doing something but then in a future video older code being shown.  Also the exercises truly need a video explaining his solution in a little more depth, rather than less than 2 minutes of showing where to go find the code to his solution from github that contains code not previously seen, particularly Exercise 2 that has some LINQ code.  Then in section 3 he introduces LINQ, some form of introduction to it should have been established in section 2 before an exercise that requires it.  If this is truly a course for beginners, it makes some rather large knowledge leaps.  I am familiar with MVC in the context of other languages and frameworks which has helped me in this course.  Was hoping to use this course to get more familiar with C# in addition to learning the ASP.NET MVC framework in addition.  Not sure yet how much knowledge I will come away with.

results.content:
The section material is well done and very helpful. However, the exercises for the later sections are fairly involved. The solutions are provided on GitHub with limited explanations. I've seen other courses run through the solution at a faster speed and prefer that method vs. doing it myself and hoping I didn't miss anything that will cause problems later on. I've started simply copying and pasting his solution instead of doing it myself to avoid future problems. Note that this changes later on in the course. The last few exercises do have a code-review, and I thank the presenter for that.

Another issue I have is with the dated material (something I realize can't be helped). There are some issues with a few of the courses that took a fair amount of time to resolve due to changes that have been made in Visual Studio and other aspects of the code. I couldn't find any help here on Udemy for the issues and had to solve them through Google searches. If you're on a current version of Visual Studio, keep that in mind.

Overall, the course material is very helpful and well presented. I initially rated the course a lot lower due to the problems above, but I can honestly say I've learned a lot about MVC programming through this course and I can see why it is rated as highly as it is. If you're an absolute beginner with web development, then you may have some problems with the dated material. Otherwise you can probably work your way through the problems, in which case the course is worth it.

results.content:
Professionally produced and presented course from a knowledgeable and skilled teacher. The exercises at the end of the sections are beautifully balanced in terms of difficulty, and really aid learning to code ASP.Net MVC in the real world. Mosh does not just show you "how to", he always explains the reasoning behind how and why we are doing what we are doing. 

I am an experienced developer (20+ years!), but have only coded ASP.Net MVC Razor and EF in a haphazard way "on the job". I wanted to bring myself bang up to date with the latest version, and make sure I had a solid and thorough understanding of the principles and practice. This course is delivering this already, and I am only partway through. Even for experienced developers, there is useful content here - Mosh gives excellent tips and tricks e.g. on productively working with VS - things that even I, who have used every version, have missed! Also, this old SQL coder is looking forward to seeing how and why CodeFirst with EF can save me time and effort.

Top marks!

It was a very good experience, but the explanations were not detailed enough, which is why many of my colleagues turned away from this course.
A problem a lot of traininers are not aware of, is that they are not explaining things well enough which should be explained, as they think its common knowledge. We cannot go in-depth with everything, because that would make this course 3x 4x longer, but it did annoy me and others that just one section took us 3-4h to complete because all the researching and troubleshooting we had to do additionally.
One example: at the very beginning of the course when creating the Project, there was NO mention that we should apply authentication. In VS Community 2019 this option is by default OFF (no authentication) so I had to recreate the project from scratch. I know its 2021 and I did not use the proper version suggested, but that was just one little hint that would have been useful as we needed this.

Why did I finished the course: because Mosh has a lot of experience and that was well worth the annoyences (which also helped to be honest, even the rebuilding of the entire project :P )

results.content:
Mosh gets 5 stars for presentation skills--it's a pleasure to watch the videos. However, it's a challenge to follow along his github project since the commits are not in the order of his presentation. They are all jumbled which is okay if you know what you are doing, but not great if you're a novice. 

Also, please don't intentionally introduce errors that you'll eventually fix in a few videos. You recommend to code and test in small bits, so if I follow that advice I get errors., so I wasted lots of time because of this. I have no problem with the times he intentionally adds an error and then corrects it in the same video segment, but not when it's only corrected 3 or 4 videos down the line. 

My suggestion to all people who are developing courses is get a novice  who is willing to work through your course as you are developing it. It took software development a while to figure out it's best to get user feedback early, so I'm sure it will take a while for course developers to figure this out as well.
results.content_html:

results.content:
Mosh is excellent in explaining the complex things in simple way.  The course is a great to beginners and intermediate level programmers. As expected, It covers the ASP.NET MVC design and implementation in detail and little bit of entity framework. 

What I don't like: 
Throughout the course, he uses lot of external packages to get the things done. But in real word, most of the big businesses do not prefer to use opensource packages for security purposes. So, it would have been better if he explained how to do the things like data grid paging and sorting, error logging into files/tables using ASP.NET code behind and/or client side scripting and then could have given direction to use the external packages. 

Overall, I would definitely recommend this course.
results.content_html:
Mosh is excellent in explaining the complex things in simple way. The course is a great to beginners and intermediate level programmers. As expected, It covers the ASP.NET MVC design and implementation in detail and little bit of entity framework.

What I don't like:
Throughout the course, he uses lot of external packages to get the things done. But in real word, most of the big businesses do not prefer to use opensource packages for security purposes. So, it would have been better if he explained how to do the things like data grid paging and sorting, error logging into files/tables using ASP.NET code behind and/or client side scripting and then could have given direction to use the external packages.

Overall, I would definitely recommend this course.

results.content: Good course. Thorough. Explains things pretty well. A few bugs are either not handled in the lectures or not handled until later lectures, so the student will sometimes spend a lot of time trying to figure out a problem without realizing that Mosh explains how to handle it in a later lecture. On the other hand, the comments left by users are often helpful and it's good experience to try debugging the code anyway.

results.content:
I don't know how good Mosh is but his teaching skill is awful.  He doesn't care if we are struggling enough with his materials.  I did exercise on section 2 and downloaded the solution of that section and it looks like the final version.  That means there has been a lot of changes in between.  It is frustrated because I don't know the error.  I finally found out that he changed the name file in Models from IdentityModels to ApplicationDbContext.  What the heck!!!  This is very important file.  He should at least notice us the changes and what he did in the back.  Otherwise, it is hard to follow the lecture.  

I totally understand that debugging should be on our own as part of learning.  However, Mosh should not do something in the back without notice and ask us to debug ourselves.  That is ridiculous.  If Mosh can't answer questions because of his limitations that is totally fine with me.  However, he should be consistent through out the course.  He should zip solution for each exercise and post on lecture content.  That is simple enough.  Git version doesn't reflect well with each section solution. 

Code first concept is great but again Mosh should outline the database would be look like at the beginning.  He should show us a sketch of database with tables structure.  After that he can add more properties later.  He failed to do so.

Given good experience with the ASP.Net, I wanted to audit to course to pick best practices recommended and used by the developers.

I understand that this course is designed for intermediate level but I was disappointed in the middle of the session where there were plugs made to entity frame work course by saying that it was out of scope for the course, Where i thought it would be helpful to include additional materials  in this course. It is my opinion. Also, in the course it was mentioned that JavaScript code refactoring will be done in the second part of the session. I don't think it was neither addressed  nor references made to the other course.

Other than that Josh you are sure awesome instructor, Course is carefully designed with core concepts easy to understand better than lot of the coursed available in the market.I can tell definitely that i picked few core concepts as well as clarified few misconceptions. Also, I am glad that i am on the same page as other developers  .

results.content:
Mosh does a great job explaining ASP.NET MVC 5 concepts, but this course is 5 stars because of how he transitions from topic to topic.

Working through the same project throughout the course simulates real world application development. Mosh practices continuous refactoring from lecture to lecture so students can follow each change and improvement he makes as they would working through problems themselves. He explains why he favors one way over another, and ultimately challenges students to consider specific aspects of solutions.

As Mosh introduces new packages into the solution, he is careful to specify package versions to ensure mirrored experiences. However, Section 10 was somewhat challenging with the introduction of Twitter's typeahead. At least for me, the remote feature did not work reliably, and I stuck with the prefetch feature with local cache clearing. This would be one of the few areas for improvement: he introduced filtering into the remote specification of typeahead before adding records filtering lectures later. This can be confusing for some people.

results.content:
While parts of the course are interesting and informative the whole lot fell apart for me when I discovered the Solution to the exercise given at the end of Section 2. Mosh doesn't cover the code contained in the solution and yet much of the added code is far more advanced than any of the concepts covered in the previous sections.

There are times in the course where explanations given are easy to follow and then there are times when the lecture is given so fast that you have to re-watch several times just to grasp the basic concepts if you manage at all. 

I understand that something as clunky as ASP is difficult to simplify beyond a certain point but I feel there are better courses out there and so I cannot recommend this to beginners if I'm honest. 

While it's a great jumping off point for a creative developer like myself I feel like a more in depth and consistent course would be more suited.

Otherwise, I'm totally happy with the course so far.  Thanks, Mosh, for making these videos and for making them affordable.

This course was kind of disappointing. It's a little bit outdated, and it skips a lot of things between videos. Between two sections new modules were added to the project that weren't there before, and no mention was ever made of it. There's never any walk-through of exercise solutions either. You're just given an exercise and a github repo where it has been solved. In other courses I'm used to having the instructor go through the solution step by step in a video, and that format is infinitely better than just "here's my code, make sure your version works for the next section too".

At some point I stopped trying to code along, because I kept getting stuck with things that wouldn't work because the course had skipped instructions or things didn't work the same way in Visual Studio 2017. Soon after, I felt like I wasn't getting anything out of it and decided to not follow through with the course.
results.content_html:

You're just given an exercise and a github repo where it has been solved. At some point I stopped trying to code along, because I kept getting stuck with things that wouldn't work because the course had skipped instructions or things didn't work the same way in Visual Studio 2017. results.content: Mosh is a really good teacher, but unfortunately this course relies too heavily on JavaScript plugins for basic functionality, while important subjects like ASP.NET Identity is explored quite shallowly. I learned lots about Entity Framework, data transfer objects, and how to create Web APIs - but, I wish it truly was a "complete ASP.NET MVC" course. I guess that sort of thing doesn't quite exist, yet(!).

results.content:
For me this is the quintessential perfect Udemy course. It won't teach you to code but if you have any level of experience with programming, especially C#, and want to learn the ins and outs of dotnet it's perfect. The pacing is great, the information covered is all relevant, self-contained, and applicable, and it manages to stay consistently on topic.

The exercises are neither impossible nor completely low-hanging fruit, serving to reinforce what was accomplished in each lesson without trying to out-clever itself. The resources are useful, the github page is clean and organized, and there are a multitude of comments that you can follow if you run into any problems.

Be warned it is a bit out of date. Though Mosh does a great job of ensuring you are using the exact same versioning as him there are some components that will not, for example, build automatically into your project. It will require a bit of googling and a bit of learning how certain systems have grown or changed to complete. It is not outside of the realm of anybody who is in the target audience of this course and most of the problems you'll encounter are well worn in the comments, expect to search a bit. Still, there isn't much more I could have asked for in a course like this. It perfectly suited my needs, didn't waste any of my time, and contained exactly what it said it would.
results.content_html:
For me this is the quintessential perfect Udemy course. It won't teach you to code but if you have any level of experience with programming, especially C#, and want to learn the ins and outs of dotnet it's perfect. The pacing is great, the information covered is all relevant, self-contained, and applicable, and it manages to stay consistently on topic.

The exercises are neither impossible nor completely low-hanging fruit, serving to reinforce what was accomplished in each lesson without trying to out-clever itself. The resources are useful, the github page is clean and organized, and there are a multitude of comments that you can follow if you run into any problems.

Be warned it is a bit out of date. Though Mosh does a great job of ensuring you are using the exact same versioning as him there are some components that will not, for example, build automatically into your project. It will require a bit of googling and a bit of learning how certain systems have grown or changed to complete. It is not outside of the realm of anybody who is in the target audience of this course and most of the problems you'll encounter are well worn in the comments, expect to search a bit. Still, there isn't much more I could have asked for in a course like this. It perfectly suited my needs, didn't waste any of my time, and contained exactly what it said it would.

results.content:
Overall this course is good at what it teaches (it is a very beginner course), however this does feel like an half a job and students won't get much out of it. Based on:
1. The tutor plugs his other courses during this course, stating to go buy his other course to learn something.
2. Every couple of videos he states that something is not in the scope of the course, and this just make me feel like i'm not getting value from the course.
3. The tutor states that a lot of the solutions on Microsoft website and stack overflow are bad implementation, yet I have seen a couple of questions asked by students. Of which the response has been its out of scope of this course and just google it, you would of thought the tutor would of at least point them in the right direction. Instead of stating to just google and end up on a website they state is bad practice. 

A good point about the course is the exercises they make it more interactive, but I do not like how he does not work through the solution (apart from one). This just ends up having to go on his GitHub and read through all his code, of which their is a couple of errors. If the tutor made a video going through the solution I feel it would be more beneficial for the students and also he would reduce his copy and paste errors in the code.

Another bad point is that I had a couple of questions during the videos, and upon looking at the Q&A section I noticed someone else already asking (these were mainly based on why the tutor did something a certain way). Unfortunately more than half of the questions I looked at are unanswered so leads me to believe the tutor and assistants are very disengaged from the course.

Overall what is taught is good but is the same as free courses and nothing special.

results.content:
Overall, a wonderful experience, I cannot find better material out there for learning ASP.NET MVC.

Mosh does a great job in this course, he has a unique approach to teaching and it pays off in the long run. He not only shows you how HE would do something, but shows you the common approaches and explains why he does it the way he does.

overall i say 4/5 stars as I think he could have done a better job with exercises and repetition (the good kind...practice)

Side note about Udemy, they ask for reviews on the course up front, so beware on course ratings as a lot of them can come without anywhere near completion of the course. (this review is after full completion of the course over the course of 1-week)

results.content:
This course is so scattered and covering isolated, lonely topics.. as if the instructor trying to demo code he collected from MSDN... none of the topics relate, nor cover a real life scenario!!
Forms: talking about HTML tags, but not even showing an example with controls (date-time picker) 
Routes: taking about pre-existing default router, but not showing any example of dynamic routes 
Restful APIs: not covering any serious topics, such build in C# WebClient, or jquery xhr, or even xmlHttpRequest heaers and tokens...!!

I was looking for any useful ASP.NET MVC course, and the content in this course is so scattered and un-relatable.. you will not even remember a week later

results.content:
Negatives: 
- Author should make video solutions for the exercises! Github link is not enough because solutions shall be explained clearly. Methods can be remain unclear because of this.

- The author is too fast in the coding videos, using too many shortcuts, jumping too fast from one window to another. 

Positives:
- Great explanations about how things work. 
- Great exercises. 
- Structure of the lectures are great and linear.

Sum: It's a great course but you should only buy it if you have experience with coding in C# (or Java, or at least you know what is OOP), using GIT and if you have experience in web development.

results.content:
I took this course for an annual training goal at work.  I'm glad I completed this course.  Mosh is a great instructor and knows the material inside and out.   I'm currently a .NET developer and by no means a beginner in this topic and still learned a million things.  I've written multiple MVC apps and still learned new things.  You'll learn MVC with sprinkles of JQuery, Bootstrap, Entity Framework, Migrations, Web API, some optimization tricks, and much more.  (Note: I use these tools everyday and wow, I learned a ton).

I bought a handful of Mosh's other courses (EF and C#, I think) for next years training.  I've recommended this course to my dev team and would recommend this course for learning MVC or learning more about MVC.  Great course.  Great Instructor.  Awesome content.
results.content_html:

Been reading about the topic from a book...
I'm getting better understanding from the explanation here than the book.... advancing much faster, and the exercise every now and then helps me revise/refresh what I have learnt and makes me take notes of what needs to be reviewed.

I like the idea of p2p forums... most of my questions are pre-asked/answered already.

The two things that would have made this way more perfect than it already is:
1) If I could download lectures to view offline in places with bad connectivity/metered connections :/
2) Less ReSharper please... lots of people are not allowed to use it at workplace and/or can't afford it individually....

results.content: I was trying to learn ASP.NET MVC 5 on my own, but that was just painful. On internet there is no good information on how to do things with this framework, most of that information is misleading, wrong, or very badly explained. It feels like this lecturer knows what he is talking about. In one hour of this course I have learned more than I did that while learning by myself for like a few weeks. It's just amazing, there is always good explanations on every thing pros and cons, a few ways to make things happen, shows be example which things are to quirky to use in real life. Also, practice parts (tasks) are really really helpful, because you not only just follow what is going on, but when get task on which you could apply what you have learned. Every lecturer should do that.

results.content:
If you want to learn ASP.NET MVC from the scratch and get to know almost all the theory parts, this is the best course. All the content has explained super perfectly.

I gave this 4 stars because, This course doesn't have a chapter about things to know when you are building a large real world application. Concepts like 'Areas', implementing the repository pattern, unit of work are missing. It would have been a real diamond if this has at-least a small chapter about these things.

Una primera parte del curso muy buena en la que aprendes la base para crear una aplicación web con muchas 'best practices' muy útiles. Una segunda parte a la que le falta profundidad.

results.content: It was a very clear instruction. I have acquired a general knowledge about ASP.net mvc and its use in real life projects. Thanks for the course.
results.content_html: It was a very clear instruction. I have acquired a general knowledge about ASP.net mvc and its use in real life projects. Thanks for the course.

results.content: Mosh is very nice and a good presenter. But he does not take the time to explain the "why" behind why he is doing something. But that's okay. I would warn any prospective student of 2 issues. 1. He does not review the solutions to the exercises. This is a problem because that is where the student gets any misconceptions corrected and learn the correct way to do something. 2. The course assistants don't know a lot. I provided screen shots and details and they said "There's nothing we can do for you." And they discouraged me from downloading the commit from github. I eventually figured out that I just needed to correct my db connection string. Something an experienced programmer would have known if they just bothered to read the error I sent them.

results.content:
Really helping me to understand MVC as a concept, Surprised by how much I have learned. 

Minor criticism would be that a few things are updated and leaves the tutorial broken until you google the problem and fix.  Its always good to solve a problem yourself but it breaks the workflow of learning and following along with the tutorial.  Minor criticism, great job overall.

In terms of making the most out of this, aside from movies and customers, create a few of your own models, views and controllers and get them to work in slightly different ways to really solidify your learning and nail the concepts you are learning.

results.content: Amazingly well crafted course, with lots of bonus nuggets.  I am going through it a second time to ensure that I really get it.  Author's explanations are clear, consise, and his voice is easy to listen to.  Some of the videos are a bit out of date, but not so much that you can't work around it.  If you need to learn MVC 5, you can't do much better than this course.

response.content: Live your enthusiasm William!  Re out of date videos, I'm planning to create a new course on ASP.NET Core. I'll keep this course as is for developers who have to maintain an MVC5 app.

results.content:
I have watched first two chapters several times, and I am still lost even though I thought I had good fundamentals in C#.

I feel like Mosh is just rushing through the videos without dedicating enough time to explain key MVC concepts.    

Also, the first Exercise is not properly explained and solution on GitHub are just confusing (haven't had chance check other).    

I think this is not a full course for "All Levels", it is just a quick tutorial and similar content is available on YouTube for free. 

On a good note, this tutorial appears to cover all aspects of MVC including deployment, I will keep the course and probably will get back to at some point in the future to get a quick refresher,  but in order to learn it, I will look for a better source. 

Sorry, but not worth the money :(

results.content:
Since I really liked the courses on C#, I wanted to extend my knowledge about the web development part.

Decided to rewrite my review, since I managed to find a workaround for the missing database implementation, which wasn't shown in the videos.
This included the installation of LocalDBExpress 2012 and copy pasting some of the files from the github repository (like IdentityConfig).
Somehow starting a new project didn't include that one, and also some of the plugins regarding the user authentication are not part of the standard template.
After the problems were fixed the course was pretty straight forward and easy to follow and didn't have any other difficulties.

results.content:
Even the best tutorials on the web assume either zero knowledge or in depth understanding of design patterns, deployment processes, software engineering terms, etc. There's never anything in between.

This course (as with Mosh's other course) assumes that you're not an idiot, and can follow along his very simple yet comprehensive instructions, without assuming you understand software engineering.

This course is great for beginners - it doesn't try to teach you anything that doesn't build on what it's already taught you before, as well as those with more experience wanting to dive into more complex subjects - it lets you know which lectures are theoretical and you can jump into more advanced topics if you like.

the structure and delivery is excellent, a lot of effort has gone into not just the lectures but also the cheat sheets and exercises.

This is what Udemy should be all about - a structured, professional course that will actually teach you a skill.

results.content:
It covers all the basics, so that even someone who isn't familliar with any MVC concepts can follow along, but it's not boring either for those who're already in the know and even shows some cool hints and tricks that those can use.

What's more impressive is that there are multiple topics covered that one might not even consider to distinctly fall under "MVC" in particular, to the extent that I might consider suggesting renaming this course to something less specific, but no less comprehensive (I feel the only ASP.NET topic that's not covered is WebForms, obviously, since this is MVC). Though I have to say once these topics are reached the complexity/comprehension level requirement increases quite a bit, with a lot more jargon flowing around, to the point where I have to sometimes replay sections that can feel like word salad.

results.content:
This is a great course that covers a lot of the important MVC topics you need so you can get started with MVC. He also covers a lot of real world best practices, tools, and technologies you can use. While he can't possibly go in depth to each and every one of these tools/technologies, it's a great starting point if you decide to use them in your projects.

I have very few complaints with this course. One of them is that there are some resharper functions that he uses in the video but doesn't explain how to do it without. This could be confusing for some beginners but experienced students can find their way around. He explains most of the resharper functions he uses so this is not a big issue. Also, it would be easier to have a "solution lecture" for each of the exercises at the end of each section. He gives you a link to the github repository but it would be easier if there was just a video for it.

results.content: There was so much I felt I was lacking by the end of this course. I still use this course to reference very specific implementations. When the TA responds to a request asking for something as basic as a better introduction to AutoMapper or a push in the right direction with "there isn't enough time to cover this", it's a bit annoying. There is also absolutely no mention of a Service or how to use Libraries, which are commonly used in the real development world AND allow for better security. I have seen many courses on Udemy that total over 400 lectures and are over 60 hours; giving an excuse such as "there isn't enough time in this course" or "it's outside of the scope of this course" repeatedly is absolute rubbish. Yes, I gained a lot of knowledge, but the amount of places I had to go to search for proper project structure and utilization of separation of concerns was absolutely crazy.

When the TA responds to a request asking for something as basic as a better introduction to AutoMapper or a push in the right direction with "there isn't enough time to cover this", it's a bit annoying. There is also absolutely no mention of a Service or how to use Libraries, which are commonly used in the real development world AND allow for better security.
