results.content:
I had a background of Web Development (1996-present) and Database Development (1994-present) and not entirely new to MVC 5. The course was reasonably well presented and the exercises proved useful but often weren't explained clearly leaving me wondering what was expected.

As the course went on however, more and more errors creeped in and often were fixed in later lectures leaving you to wonder what had you done wrong at the time - a perfect example of this is a known bug in typeahead which, for someone less experienced would have struggled. Clearly the code wasn't checked before recording each lecture and often at the end there would be mistakes in what was shown and again, a new or less experienced developer may not spot the mistakes.

The course focused on the use of Chrome which, while heavily used, resulted in a lot of time trying to figure out why the validation wasn't working because the information communicated didn't work in other browsers (Edge, FireFox and IE were all non-functioning) and one thing anyone who has done extensive web development over the years should appreciate is the need to test across all browsers. The issue was simply addressed in this case by reading official documentation - submitHandler does indeed pass in the event as the second parameter Mosh, go look it up.

One  bad database design practice that was communicated was the addition of count field for the video rentals rather than showing users how counting could be done properly - having many records shouldn't cause a database to perform poorly. This had me face palming, shaking my head and wanting to scream at the screen for such a poorly thought out technique.

What I took away from the course the most is the ease of installing packages and using the console to create migrations for upgrading databases, something I am keen to learn more about.

What I found poor about this course: subtitles where shockingly bad, lack of any communitation or support from Mosh on the Q&A even when he introduced poor code or buggy packages, a few quizzes throughout wouldn't go amiss and the course refers to itself as a Complete course but I felt not all the useful information was there and so far from complete.

Would I recommend this particular course to a colleague or person looking to learn - probably not and especially not to an experienced developer looking to learn MVC.
results.content_html:

Highly recommend.

results.content:
As with all courses by Mosh, this course is comprehensive, easy to follow and very helpful.

Mosh takes his time to not only show how, but also explain why things are done a certain way (benefits, ease of use, real-world examples).

Although, as a computer geek, I wouldn't mind even more in-depth information (such as diving into the framework code to show the internal code works), I realize that this might be too much for an average student. 
Mosh, however, gives a lot of pointers on what to read and research if you want to know more about a certain topic.

Overall a fantastic course by a wonderful instructor.
Can't wait for more courses by Mosh!

Course materials are in easily consumed bite-size chunks, with focus on all the aspects needed to deliver an MVC5 website - not just the basics. Unexpected gems covering concepts and tools such as: EF Code-first migrations, DTOs, AutoMapper, ELMAH, and Glimpse provided many "Aha!" moments. I'd thoroughly recommend this course.

results.content:
This course provides you with a solid foundation of the ASP.NET  architecture.

However the two best things I found about this course were:

- Exercises / challenges at the end of every section to practice the concepts taught
- Concepts applied to a real world application, showing you exactly how all the components are integrated together and how you can do this in your own projects.

Since completing the course, I have created a couple of my own applications in ASP.NET MVC 5 using the techniques taught. I have found that the lectures and git hub repository have been  great reference material.

Even though Microsoft recommend that you start new applications in ASP.NET Core, this course is still worth taking as many of the concepts are the same in both ASP.NET MVC 5 and ASP.NET Core. plus transitioning over with a solid knowledge of ASP.NET MVC 5 makes the process easier and allows you to understand whats different about the two technologies.

My only criticism is that parts of the course are outdated, and you may find yourself having to actually start the project again if you don't use the correct project settings at the start of the course, so be mindful. It would be extremely helpful if these outdated lectures were updated by the creators. Thankfully the course has it's own little community and many of the later problems you encounter have already been solved by people on the discussion board.

Furthermore the instructor states in one of the last lectures that there is a PDF of exercises that the students can complete to solidify their understanding of the concepts taught in the course. However the exercises were never added by the instructor (as far as I am aware.)

results.content: Up until the "exercises" appeared, my rating was holding strong at 5. Great teaching style. Then when I saw that the exercises make us add new code to solve suggested problems, and the "solutions" are only available as source code from a Github repo, my rating instantly dropped to a 3. I would rather SEE the solution walked through on video so the entire BIG PICTURE comes together in my mind instead of forcing me to spend time to try it myself and/or hunt around in source code files to see how it works. I learn best via "Matrix style". I watch courses at 2X speed and rapidly absorb the BIG PICTURE. If the VIDEO isn't there, I can't learn it in my preferred way. Takes too long to go hunt around in source code. Might as well go read MS tutorial pages.

results.content:
Great course! One of the best I have taken on Udemy. The sample project is big enough to be an effective learning experience and Mosh walks through the whole process in an orderly fashion. 

He explains each step and provides a variety of ways to do things. You get exposure to multiple approaches without being overwhelmed. One of the things l like about Mosh's classes is that he demonstrates a variety of tools and techniques and this class is no exception. You will come away with a number of potential tools to add to your web developer's developers toolkit.

The only improvement I would suggest is in Section 1, Lecture 4, add a small call-out to make sure students change the default authentication setting when initially creating the class project. The latest versions of Visual Studio have a different default setting than what was used in the video and that small change has a big impact on getting the Entity Framework working later on. For students with prior experience with Entity Framework this is probably not a problem but for newer folks it can be quite difficult (as evidenced by some comments on the Q&A board).

There are a few other very minor things that have changed in the tools and packages used due to new versions being released since the video was recorded but they aren't too bad and even beginners should be able to work past them.

For any beginners reading this far, at the beginning of the class Mosh outlines some prerequisite knowledge considerations for beginners vs more experienced students. I strongly recommend beginners take his advice to heart. My recommendation is that beginners consider going through his Entity Framework (EF) class BEFORE taking this class if they do not have prior experience with EF. There is plenty to learn in this class just focusing on ASP. EF is covered enough to get you up and running in this class but it is a steep curve if you have no prior experience and you will only get a VERY narrow exposure to the framework. The EF class moves along quickly so it doesn't take a lot of time. Having that EF knowledge going in to this ASP class will allow you to focus on learning ASP instead of trying to learn both ASP and EF at the same time.  

Thanks for a great course Mosh. I am looking forward to seeing what you release next.

For students with prior experience with Entity Framework this is probably not a problem but for newer folks it can be quite difficult (as evidenced by some comments on the Q&A board).

There are a few other very minor things that have changed in the tools and packages used due to new versions being released since the video was recorded but they aren't too bad and even beginners should be able to work past them.

For any beginners reading this far, at the beginning of the class Mosh outlines some prerequisite knowledge considerations for beginners vs more experienced students. I strongly recommend beginners take his advice to heart. My recommendation is that beginners consider going through his Entity Framework (EF) class BEFORE taking this class if they do not have prior experience with EF. There is plenty to learn in this class just focusing on ASP. EF is covered enough to get you up and running in this class but it is a steep curve if you have no prior experience and you will only get a VERY narrow exposure to the framework. The EF class moves along quickly so it doesn't take a lot of time. Having that EF knowledge going in to this ASP class will allow you to focus on learning ASP instead of trying to learn both ASP and EF at the same time.

Thanks for a great course Mosh. I am looking forward to seeing what you release next.

results.content:
I have taken plenty of courses on Udemy in programming, both free and paid courses. This is one of the shortest courses I bought, only 7,5h of video material. I took me 9 days of full-time studies to finish.

Why did I only study less than 1 hours every day? Well, these courses are so compressed that I think this course is equivalent to a 40+ hour-course.

The instructor is clear and to the point, very competent in software engineering and teaches best practises, he starts from the very beginning and builds upon that for a good end-result. He doesn't try to fit everything in the course, but mentions about technologies and best practices and where to learn more. The lectures are well rehearsed and there's not "dead time". 
Another plus is that the sound and music are top notch and adds to the already positive experience.

If I have the time I will buy more courses from Mosh. I don't think I need to find another instructor soon.

results.content:
This is a great course for anybody who wants to start learning about the ASP.NET MVC framework. It also made me realized the benefits of code-first approach to databases.

The course is based on a practical test application that are being developed throughout the lectures. This works very well as a teaching model.

The course is NOT a beginners programming course -- which is a good thing. You'll need to know the basics of programming in C#. Also knowing your way around GitHub is an advantage.

In the lectures Mosh is using ReSharper shortcuts but you can easily follow along without it, as I did. You'll probably learn a few extra things that way, too.

Some of lectures are a getting a little dated (almost 3 years now). This can easily lead to errors by the student since the current version of Visual Studio is a little different than the one Mosh is using in the course. Especially in the beginning of the course where all the setup of the test application is done. However, when you get pass section 3, it does not matter for the rest of the course.

I would have rated the course 5 stars had it been up to date.

results.content: This was one of the best courses I've taken so far on Udemy. At first my intention was to take it solely as a refresher, since I hadn't programmed in MVC for a while. But this course was much more than that. The use of code first and migrations, for example, was the answer I needed to the haunting problem of database versioning. As I learned about new .NET features and great third parties components, I just wondered why no architect never used them in any of our last projects. Now I feel confident to start a new web application from scratch and implement all the professional features that decent web systems require. No doubt this course made me a better programmer.

results.content:
This is the first complete course I've completed on this site and I've been very impressed with it. The instructor is engaging and has obviously put a lot of work into the course - the production value is great. 

The only reason this loses half a star from me is that the exercises don't always have a code review after them, so you'll need to go and view the course GitHub to figure out whats changed. 

This perhaps won't be an issue for most, but I'm a beginner (and probably out of my depth a bit) so a walk-through of the solution would've have been great. The penultimate section of this course is a great example of how this could have been done.

All in all, a great course that I would happily recommend to others!

results.content:
My biggest issue with the course so far is Mosh's approach to explaining solutions to exercises - he doesn't, he just sends you to rummage through his Github. Someone (maybe Mosh) might say that this is good training for independent work or something, rather than handing me solutions on a platter, but I think he could've put more of an effort there. 

The course is full of good valuable information but I think now (at the midway point) Mosh's explanations are becoming more and more "this is the way it is because it is" and not explaining much of the mechanisms behind the code and practices he shows, which is also putting an onus on me to figure things out by myself that I think is inappropriate for a paid course.

results.content: I'm an experienced .Net Windows developer, but not in ASP.NET or MVC. Mosh's explanations are very clear and easy to follow. He's got a very motivating way of explaining. You won't get bored. You'll pause the video and write the same code as him. I like the way that he doesn't use boilerplate code, but puts it together from scratch, explaining each part in just enough detail. There are however some moments where the content isn't completely up to date (Current Bootstrap version, Postman Chrome extension), this could slow down complete beginners a bit, but didn't bother me too much as it gave me a good excuse to dig in to the details and learn even more deeply.  If you do get stuck the course questions are a good place to look, and of course the internet has countless sources of help.  I used StackOverflow quite a lot to help me with jquery.  I even added a jquery-io datepicker as a personal challenge!  I wholeheartedly recommend this course as well as Mosh's other .NET courses on Entity Framework and C#.

results.content: This is a great course for the fundamentals of ASP.NET MVC. Mosh is a great teacher and the layout of the course is absolutely fantastic. Just as a warning, there are a lot of extra concepts (AJAX, JQuery, Entity and Identity framework, etc) that are touched upon in this course and examples shown, but you will likely need to do your own research or learn them separate. These are not part of ASP.NET MVC but are supplemental to it. I think one of the most valuable things in this course is that Mosh really clearly outlines bad coding practices and great, clean solutions.

It covers many areas in MVC and gives you many directions.
It's worth mentioning that since the topic is too big, we shouldn't criticize Mosh for not covering some things deeply.
After all, if want to be a professional developer it's yours responsibility to go deeper.
Once again, thank you very much Mosh.

results.content: I'm sorry Mosh to not be able to be as positive as I was about other courses of yours I followed. This is because of what you gave as an assignment in part 19 of this course. There isn't an "Up to now" followed by an "After this" where one can track their own actions, partly because a great deal of what was shown seems to have been for examplary purposes, and not to be part of an actual "up-to-now" stage. And then when I go to your Git site I see many things that were supposed to be implemented to get to the end result that weren't (sufficiently) covered in the videos up to that point, meening that one can easily get discouraged to follow along or through after seeing what was apparantly necessary to get there. I may be enthousiastic about ASP.NET MVC, and won't give up that easily, but I am still just ancle deep in this material and need more to go by if I am to get all of it. Please don't skip on things that need more explaning. Otherwise you are a good teacher.

results.content:
Mosh is very passionate about what he does and it shows in his tone, presentation, and structures of this course. I have learned a lot from this course on ASP.NET MVC 5 architecture and I feel can easily implement a basic website with Restful api on my own. Some of the material feels outdated but the concepts remain the same. Mosh also wants you to have good coding practices and give good case scenarios where such bad coding practices can lead you down a hard to debug path if you are not careful. 

However, this course left me wanting more when it came to the complex topics: 

1.  I wanted to know how to refactor code to separate the javascript code away from the views. 

2. I wanted to dive deeper into understanding ASP.NET Identity and how Microsoft dealt with security features, authentication, and Authorization when it came to using Rest API's. 

3. I also wanted to be more familiar with RSA key generation to encrypt web.config connection strings. 

In actuality, what you do get is more than enough for what you pay for. 

I feel like I'll start diving deeper into the missing topics anyway because Mosh opened up more questions to explore (maybe for future courses?).

results.content:
This course opened for me the path to becoming a great ASP.NET MVC 5 developer by presenting a lot of valuable and professional information and technics, and it helped me to understand how I should learn better. Before this course, I knew almost nothing about the framework, but I think it is important to have at least intermediate knowledge in C# to follow along. Especially if you get lost on lambda expressions, I recommend learning about them at first. 
Mosh explains almost every topic in great detail, but for me, being a slow learner, it was crucial to not just listen to what he says and follow along with the code in hope that it will all just make since later, but to reflect on the knowledge I have just received. If you are not familiar with learning through reflection, I recommend googling it and finding out more about this technique. Whenever Mosh explained something that did not quite make sense to me, I had to replay that part for N amount of times until I do understand it and after that, I just tried to paraphrase what he said and write it down as comments in my own words. This approach does take quite some time. I think I spend at least 35 to 45 hours in general on this course, if not more including all the exercises that Mosh gives you to do. Btw, do all of them! Do not just copy what he did! Try to have a good understanding of the problem before you are going to solve it. Make a small list of steps that are necessary to complete the task (I made a separate Exercises.txt folder for that) by recalling what Mosh did in his lectures. Moreover, try to execute it yourself, without looking at his code at first. But also, if you face a problem that you can't solve for 20 minutes, don't waste your time as I did, go and seek help either from questions on the board or the code that Mosh provides on GitHub.

results.content:
Overall, I thought the course was very helpful. I feel like I have a solid understanding of the fundamentals of ASP.NET MVC, which was the purpose of the course. I learned how to use some cool new tools in VS that I didn't know about before and a LOT about code first development using EF, which I think will be beneficial down the road.

However, I was left with some confusion regarding API Controllers Vs. "MVC" Controllers and when to use which. Coming in, I was of the understanding that all controller responses should be designed for public consumption, and that your app should be part of that public population. I discovered, going through your course, that this can be much more complicated and time-consuming, in some scenarios, that using a custom "MVC" controller. I thought it was interesting that the instructor chose to implement the former (Web API) for the examples for Customers and Movies without elaborating on this a bit more. 

Again, overall, a VERY solid course. You won't regret spending the time or money.
